PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to his recent efforts to persuade leading banks and life offices to bear the major burden of providing up to $1 billion in risk capital for small and medium sized businesses. Will the Minister confirm that this proposal has been killed off because the Government agrees with the industry that there is no logic in handing over vast sums of money to those with considerably less expertise, especially when the industry is already involved in a number of similar initiatives? Will the Minister also confirm that this harebrained idea has been permanently shelved and not simply deferred so that the Minister can have another go at a later date?

—Firstly, I do not agree with the proposition in the first part of the honourable senator's question. Secondly, I think the significant reaction in large sections of the industry was that the financial sector in Australia lacks the required expertise. That view was put to me in writing on several occasions by financial institutions. It was never a question of government expertise; it was never a question of government involvement in funds administration. It was a question of private sector involvement in funds administration. The general view was that it lacked the expertise, which is an unfortunate thing for this country. In regard to the latter part of the honourable senator's question, discussions are still proceeding with various institutions.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to a recent speech by Sir Arvi Parbo in which he talked about the global marketplace and the success of transnational companies that have forged alliances with their traditional competitors. What initiatives has the Government introduced to stimulate industry to seek development partners specialising in the same or similar products in other countries, if any? Is the Minister aware of any industries which may already be working in partnership with similar industries in other countries to produce world class products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the best illustration of this is to look at Australia's top 20 exporters compared with Australia's top 20 exporters of a few years ago. If we look at today's top 20 exporters, we will see in that list the emergence of telecommunications companies, computer hardware and software companies and even motor vehicle companies which were not there several years ago. Of course, pre-eminent among them all we will see that the major exporter of Australian manufactured goods now is Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd with steel. It was not there among the top exporters a few years ago. A new range of companies has moved into that position.

ANSWER.PARA: I regard the comments of Sir Arvi Parbo as being constructive, particularly as they come from a leading Australian industrialist. With some notable exceptions, Australian industry has been slow to get into the global marketplace through strategic alliances. There are some good examples, apart from those I have mentioned in terms of manufacturing performers, such as the North West Shelf team and the frigate and submarine projects, which are predominantly domestically focused but do involve substantial interrelationships with overseas companies.

Some industries are, however, ahead of the game. I speak of the aerospace, telecommunications and information technology industries. For example, the significant growth in exports in the information technology industries has been done by alliances between major international and local computer companies, particularly software companies. Several local companies have had their products and technologies incorporated into international product lines and won large export orders as a result. The momentum of that process is building, too.

Similarly, in the aerospace industry Hawker De Havilland Ltd, for example, is now in a risk sharing arrangement with McDonnell Douglas Ltd to build a helicopter, Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd is working closely with Airbus in its A330 project, and so on. I think that the point of the question is that other sectors must follow these examples if they are to prosper in the next century. Sir Arvi's words, to that extent, are apt; and I hope his audience took them to heart. The Government is, of course, encouraging that process, but it is up to firms to actually do it in the context of commercial relationships.

I ask the Minister: in view of the recent decision by the Premier of Western Australia, Carmen Lawrence, to close down the now discredited Australian Labor Party Premiers slush fund, which was administered by the then Premier, Brian Burke, and the Minister's colleague Senator Beahan to, amongst other things, pay convicted phone tapper Robert Smith to spy on Opposition members of parliament, has the Minister discussed this or any related matter with the former Premier and has the Minister now changed his view about the propriety of the ambassador, particularly given the decision of Premier Lawrence?

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is it the case that women in the Australian Federal Police are serving in Cyprus? If so, how long have they been there and are their duties comparable to those of male Australian Federal Police officers, who have been serving in Cyprus for many years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that female Australian Federal Police officers have been serving with the contingent in Cyprus since 1988. At the moment there are two female officers in the Cyprus contingent. Senator Maguire would be aware that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, of which he is Chairman, is holding an inquiry into Australian peacekeeping operations around the world. The fact is that for the last 26 years Australia has made a contingent of police officers available to the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus as part of the international efforts to enhance stability and order on that island.

ANSWER.PARA: I visited the contingent in July, 18 months ago, and I found that there was a very high regard for the Australian Federal Police in the maintaining of the cease-fire, in its aid to the Red Cross as the international committee requested assistance from time to time, and generally in the way in which it gave a certain security to the two communities-Turkish and Greek-in relation to their difficult relationships across the buffer zone, particularly in regard to locating, interviewing and providing aid to Turkish or Greek Cypriots living in the opposite community.

I believe that the role of the Australian Federal Police has been very beneficial as far as both of those communities are concerned. I am quite sure that the fact that female officers are now able to work in an operational role within that contingent has also been of great assistance.

General Milner, the Canadian commander of the force on Cyprus, appears to take a more enlightened attitude than some of his predecessors as regards the contribution which female police officers can make operationally in Cyprus. I believe that at the moment the way in which female officers are deployed operationally indicates that he has an appreciation-as, of course, Australia does-of the principles of equal employment opportunity, which Senator Maguire has been interested to see observed in this respect. I believe that the Australian Federal Police operation in Cyprus has played a very substantial role in maintaining good relations between the Greek and Turkish communities on that island. I know that has been recognised by the representatives of both those communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the failure of our trade mission to change the decision of the United States Government to double wheat subsidies to American farmers under its export enhancement program (EEP). I ask: did the Australian Government point out to the United States of America that its decision is contrary to its own professed commitment to reduce agricultural subsidies the world over and to bring them under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade? Secondly, did the Australian Government also advise the United States that Australia is no longer prepared to sacrifice Australian farmers and Australian industry while the US and the European Community (EC) ignore their obligations, and that Australia will now feel free to use carefully selected bounties, subsidies and tariffs to advance the interests of Australian industries and primary producers? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To describe the bipartisan mission led by Dr Blewett which visited Washington between 6 and 9 March as a failure, as Senator Spindler does, implies expectations of success of that mission in terms of changing the United States position at this stage which were simply not in the real world. The point of the matter is that, in terms of what was realistically achievable, Dr Blewett's words speak for themselves when he said, as reported, that on balance the outcome of the mission was better than expected but not as good as hoped. What the mission did was to make plain to officials in the Administration and members of Congress the damage that the fallout of the export enhancement program was causing fair trading nations such as Australia, forcefully registering yet again the very deep concern of the Australian Parliament and people about the damage being done to the wheat industry in particular by EEP subsidies.

ANSWER.PARA: The mission was given two assurances about better targeting of the program, which provides some small degree of hope that the damage caused to Australian farmers by the EEP might be reduced. In the first place, the Bush Administration did undertake to take what it described as all possible care to avoid disruption by the EEP to Australia's traditional wheat markets, including the Middle East, in the post-war period, which is obviously potentially of great significance. Secondly, the Administration has also agreed to consider a proposal to establish a process of consultation with Australia on sales under the EEP. It does not sound like very much but it would be a very considerable advance on what the situation is at the moment, where these subsidies come into particular markets out of a clear blue sky.

Almost every congressman that the delegation saw accepted that the American subsidies under the EEP did impact on Australian sales, despite the stated intention of the EEP simply to challenge the unfair trading practices that hurt US exports, particularly those of the EC. It was made clear, nevertheless-and this I guess is what we all expected the response to be-that the US would maintain the basic EEP for as long as the European Community continued its massive agricultural subsidies. The US Congress will very shortly-and this, of course, governed the timing of the mission-be considering a Bill which would increase EEP expenditure for the fiscal year 1991 from $US425m to $US900m. It does seem that, despite the efforts of the mission and other representations that we have been making, the Bill is likely to pass, given its very widespread support within Congress. It is not clear, however, at this stage whether the passage will be for the full amount requested, and any reduction in that respect will, of course, be helpful.

So I think one can say that the visit of the delegation to Washington has clearly underlined, which we wanted to do, the importance of a satisfactory outcome to the Uruguay Round, especially on agriculture, and left no doubt in anyone's mind that the Cairns Group of countries, led by Australia, are not going to rest until we achieve in this respect a more liberal international trading regime.

The last part of Senator Spindler's question talks in terms of bounties, subsidies, tariffs and all the rest of the enthusiastic agenda now being promoted by some people. The Government's response to the appropriate place of measures of this kind in the country's total industry policy will, of course, emerge in the Prime Minister's statement and associated statements to be made tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I preface my question by saying that the Minister would be aware of media comments about recent studies on asbestos by Worksafe Australia. Do the major findings of the study indicate a need for further work to be undertaken to overcome the problems associated with asbestos?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator West's question is, of course, yes. A fortnight ago I had the privilege of releasing a study that Worksafe Australia had conducted-a study which took six years to complete, was refereed by world experts and is regarded as world-class research. That study found a direct causal link between the amount of exposure workers might have to asbestos and the propensity to contract the lung cancer mesothelioma. The study also made a finding in respect of what had hitherto been a point of some contention-whether the inhalation of blue asbestos fibres was the sole cause or whether there was indeed a toxic potency in the inhalation of white asbestos fibres of the same degree. The study found in that respect that while white asbestos fibres are unlikely to have the same potency as blue asbestos fibres, in fact the lung can clear them more quickly. White, blue and, indeed, brown asbestos are extremely toxic and are likely to give rise, if exposure has been at all prolonged, to the lung disease mesothelioma.

ANSWER.PARA: The study also found that, because of the biological time taken for these diseases to incubate-there is a 35-year gestation period for these diseases to occur-when they manifest themselves in the lung, there is no known cure. When one is diagnosed as having the disease, there is no way one can be cured, and life expectancy from that point on is about seven months. It has been found that the number of people likely to die from mesothelioma between now and 2010 is greater than the known number of people expected to die because of the AIDS virus.

Worksafe Australia is therefore giving urgent attention to a review of standards for exposure to asbestos. While at the present time it thinks its standards are adequate, in the light of these findings it will review those standards.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FUNDING OF HIGHER EDUCATION IN QUEENSLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, refers to the continued underfunding of higher education in Queensland. Given that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has stated that only 12 of every 1,000 students in north Queensland go on to higher education when the figure is 29 per thousand in Canberra and Melbourne, and given that three-quarters of the students at a far north Queensland youth congress I attended yesterday said the lack of a campus in Cairns might prevent them from going to university, why does this Government continue to underfund higher education in Queensland, particularly in north Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know where Senator O'Chee was last week when Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked a similar sort of question. He cites one set of figures. I think it is fair to reflect also in any answer that should be given to him that the proportion of students going from secondary to tertiary education in Queensland is in fact, I believe, the highest in all States of the Commonwealth. That must reflect the Government's priorities and initiatives.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in response to Senator Bjelke-Petersen last week, the Government in its approach to education, both secondary and tertiary, will ensure that children and students throughout the country do have equal access to education and opportunities through that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—Senator Parer says, `Rubbish'. It is a pity that in his case we could not have made it retrospective. The Government, through Mr Dawkins, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, and also Mr Baldwin, has a commitment to ensure that students throughout the country do have equal access to education especially on a tertiary level.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is fair to say that the claims that were made last week by Senator Bjelke-Petersen and by Senator O'Chee this morning are difficult to substantiate. When we look, for instance, at Queensland's share of funding in higher education, we should recognise that in allocating growth amongst the States and Territories the Commonwealth does take into account a range of factors, including the current levels of participation and unmet demand and projected figure demand associated with population growth increasing to year 12 enrolments.

Having considered these factors, the Commonwealth has recognised Queensland's case for a share of growth above its population share, and this is also the case for some other States. The growth allocations provided to Queensland by the Commonwealth are such that Queensland will receive 25 per cent, 1,215 places, of all additional intakes in 1991 and 23 per cent over the years 1991 and 1993, well above its population share of 17 per cent. That is a direct rebuttal to the essential point that Senator O'Chee makes.

I will go further: in 1990 the higher education participation rate in Queensland was slightly below the national rate-39 per 1,000 of 17 to 64-year-olds compared with 40 per 1,000 nationally. There are some other States-notably New South Wales-which have the same or lower participation rates than Queensland. Their rate is 37 per 1,000, Tasmania is 34 per 1,000, and South Australia and the Northern Territory are about 39 per 1,000. Further to that, it is estimated that on 1990 figures an additional 13,200 students would have been required to bring New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory to the 1990 national rate.

I go back to the point that I made in terms of funding for the current financial year. In the years 1991 to 1993, Queensland will receive over and above its entitlement in the provision of growth allocations to tertiary education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. If the Minister's answer is correct, then why is the Minister at odds with his own Labor Party Premier in Queensland who has said that Queensland remains underfunded by some 4,000 places a year? Why is it the case that the document tabled in December shows that this Government is unwilling to provide a campus in Cairns where the participation rate is not 39 per 1,000 but 12 per 1,000?

—Senator O'Chee could probably best direct the first part of his question to the State Premier of Queensland. In respect of the second part of his question, I should repeat the fact that the Government's priorities in this area are to ensure equal access. To that extent, we have ensured that over the next three years Queenslanders will have access to a greater level of intake to tertiary higher education than other parts of Australia.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. There is a debate later today on higher education. I ask the Minister, because it is relevant to that later debate today, to table the paper from which he was quoting containing the figures with regard to Queensland.
—Will the Minister table the document?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask: was the Minister present at a conference on the weekend convened by the Industrial Relations Society of South Australia to examine policies and practices in the Australian industrial relations environment? At that conference, was the employers perspective, as articulated by Mr Ian Spicer of the Confederation of Australian Industry, supportive of a number of the Australian Government's current programs and initiatives within the Australian industrial relations system? Can the Minister advise the Senate as to what conclusions might possibly be drawn from Mr Spicer's observations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the weekend I did have the pleasure, at its invitation, of addressing the Australian Industrial Relations Society Convention. I think it was quite a successful one, and that is a tribute to the organisers of that convention. I was struck at the time by the amount of common ground evident between the conference participants on their vision of Australian industrial relations for the future.

ANSWER.PARA: It has become increasingly apparent to me that there is currently an unprecedented converging of views between the main employer bodies, the ACTU and the governments on the direction for change in the industrial relations system. I must say, however, that despite this convergence the Opposition remains as much out on a limb with its non-practical, sand-castles in the air industrial relations policy.

The best example of that is, I think, Mr Alan Brown in Victoria who is currently threatening to use parliamentary numbers to block a consensus reform to industrial relations and has achieved nothing other than the absolute stout defence of those reforms by employer organisations, and criticism of his actions by employers as well as the other participants in industrial relations.

Mr Spicer made a speech at the South Australian conference, and that speech is a graphic example of what I mean. In his speech, Mr Spicer made the following points. One, that the existing system is `able to deliver extraordinary flexibility, if that is what the employer really wants'. `An employer', he went on to point out, `can choose between a regime of minimum rates awards with enterprise flexibility provisions, enterprise specific paid rates awards, or section 115 certified agreements to suit the needs of any particular enterprise; and that following the forthcoming Industrial Relations Commission decision on the National Wage Case, there may soon be scope for enterprise bargaining within the system'.

Mr Spicer was at pains to point out that the Industrial Relations Commission has a very important role to play in managing the change to a more decentralised system. Mr Spicer pointed out that the lack of management skills and lack of employee participation are real bottlenecks in the reform process under way through award restructuring.

To its credit, the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) is undertaking a crash training course of some 6,000 managers from all over Australia-various States, industries and localities-for the next three months. That is a course which the Commonwealth Government is funding in part with the CAI to better equip managers at middle management level with industrial relations responsibilities to take advantage of the avenues of flexibility offered by the current system.

Mr Spicer concluded, `It is no good blaming the system for not delivering if we have not also delivered'-in talking of himself-`in terms of our management practices. It is no good blaming the system if we do not have the courage or ability to get the benefits which are currently available from it'.

Of course, Mr Spicer was not complacent about the current system and made some useful suggestions for further change. There do remain areas where there are disagreements between ourselves as the Government and the employer groups, particularly the way in which we view the importance of equity considerations in these matters. However, the fact remains that this Government, through its practical measures undertaken over the past years to reform the industrial relations system in this country, has provided a framework for employers to achieve improvements in productivity and efficiency, and that employers generally understand that.

People like the Opposition, who blame the industrial relations system for hindering change, are, in the words of Mr Spicer, the Chief Executive of the Confederation of Australian Industry, `simply making excuses for those who want to avoid the hard task of planning for change and then setting about achieving its delivery'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Government in its Budget Papers has indicated that, with the scheduled completion of the current program of major asset sales, such revenue will no longer be available to mitigate the net growth in forward estimate outlays. Given the Budget surplus shortfall, will the Government need to increase the number of assets it sells in order to raise the funds necessary to meet the growth in outlays? If so, what are they?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said on numerous occasions in the Senate, the decline in the surplus is essentially a counter-cyclical decline in the surplus. We are very lucky to have had in this country a surplus of the order that we had. It is counter-cyclical in the sense that unemployment benefits have risen, corporate profits have been reduced as a result of the recession, and corporate tax has accordingly been reduced. In addition to that, there have been some reductions in the surplus as a result of Government policy: for example, approximately $1 billion associated with the wage-tax trade-off, some $300m which has gone to the wool industry, and some $700m associated with the sale of the pipeline which was lost as a result of the decision by the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator's question is couched on the assumption that, because there is a decline in the surplus, therefore that decline should be compensated for by further sales of assets. That is not the view of the Government. As the economy recovers, the structural surplus will come back as corporate profits rise and unemployment declines. It is not the view that one compensates for these things by a further program of asset sales as a means of redressing an imbalance in the Budget. That has never been so and it is not our view now. That view was fairly prevalent in the early years of the Thatcher Government in England and has become somewhat discredited since, particularly as a result of the North Sea oil.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, affects every Australian, since it relates to the Medicare card. Has the Privacy Commissioner endorsed the Government's plan to use Medicare cards to check eligibility for pharmaceutical benefits by having a direct compulsory computer link-up between pharmacists and the Health Insurance Commission? A month prior to the last Federal election, due to the Privacy Commissioner's concerns, the Government aborted the system. Do the Privacy Commissioner's concerns still apply to this system and, if so, what has the Government done to allay those concerns?

—As I indicated last week, the Privacy Commissioner has certainly been involved in lengthy discussions and deliberations with the Minister concerning the issue of the Medicare card, which will be used in relation to entitlement to pharmaceutical benefits. I believe that those discussions, whilst continuing, have laid a foundation where the Privacy Commissioner has approved the proposal. I do not know about every aspect; I do not know whether I can reply in relation to each part of the project and how it will be implemented piece by piece. But certainly as to endorsing the proposal in the large, I believe that the Privacy Commissioner has done that, but there has never been any question that his involvement should stop with that general endorsement. I believe that he is being consulted as to the details of the implementation of the project.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Has the Commissioner expressed concerns about the compulsory transmission scheme, not the reissuing of Medicare cards?
—I will seek further advice on that from the relevant Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. With agreement in the South Australian House of Assembly to the introduction of a 0.05 blood alcohol level for drivers and other measures to improve road safety as part of the Federal Government's road safety initiative package, could the Minister advise the progress on the funding that South Australia will receive for black spot treatment in that State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is absolutely true that the South Australian Legislative Assembly last week approved a package of road reform measures that had been proposed to it by the South Australian Minister of Transport, Frank Blevins. Those reforms form part of the Federal Government's 10-point package of road safety reforms that are contingent on being accepted in respect of delivering the additional road funding for the black spot program.

ANSWER.PARA: I know that in South Australia, as certainly happened in the Northern Territory, there was a particularly active and hot debate on the package and particularly one aspect of it; that is, the reduction of blood alcohol levels from .08 to .05. I would certainly like to take this opportunity of congratulating both the South Australian Government and the South Australian Legislative Assembly for being far-sighted enough, despite the controversy, to move to adopt these programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What other States have .05?

—It is still a matter of some controversy in the Northern Territory where the Minister for Transport does not want to accept it. As a result of the initiatives by the South Australian Government, the Minister for Land Transport, Bob Brown, announced last weekend that the Federal Government will approve additional funding for the South Australian black spot program. That will deliver some $12m in additional funding to South Australia over the next three years, $5.4m of which will be delivered this fiscal year.

—Can the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs reassure the citrus industry that he has no intention of backing away from statements made in his press release of 29 November last year that `all fruit juice is to carry country of origin labels'? Can the Minister confirm that the national labelling standard will be gazetted exactly as he indicated? Can he explain why the South Australian Government gazetted a much watered down version of that promised standard on 20 December 1990, which states only that fruit juice labels have to indicate the presence of imported ingredients, and not the quantity or the country of origin? Does this mean the Minister is no longer going to insist on a national standard with country of origin labelling? If so, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the need for consumers to be able to exercise their power in the marketplace to support Australian farmers, orchardists and those involved in various horticultural pursuits, I believe it is extremely essential that they be given the fullest information on the label of the origin of the goods which they purchase. I believe that the health Ministers, who are in charge of food labelling laws around Australia, are in general agreement with that principle.

ANSWER.PARA: If South Australia has acted in the way that is suggested by Senator Olsen, I believe that that is because it is acting to deal with a matter of concern in South Australia but before all health Ministers have a chance, through their combined and joint forum, to consider the proposal which I put to them late last year. I believe in the joint discussions that will be held and the consultations and deliberations which precede that that the merit of the proposal I put will be apparent and ought to be adopted as an Australia-wide standard. As I said, I am in the hands of various health Ministers around Australia in that regard.

As to the question of indicating the fact that the ingredients in, say, a fruit juice come from overseas, where there is a mixture of juices from three or four different overseas countries it may be difficult to indicate exactly which countries of origin contributed to the particular bottle or container of orange juice and it may be sufficient for the consumer to know that the ingredients were imported. That should be sufficient to enable a distinction to be made between that juice and one which is definitely a product of Australia if the consumer is to act in support of the Australian orchardists.

I do not think that that matter has been resolved. I look forward to further discussions with the health Ministers about how Australian consumers might be able to support Australian industry in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of reports of unrest at the Vatukoula goldmine in Fiji, which is owned by a subsidiary of the Australian company Western Mining Corporation (WMC)? Can the Minister confirm that the unrest is the result of a dispute over allegations of racism and complaints about safety and living conditions, pay and union recognition? Has the Government taken any action in relation to this dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a strike and reports of a fear of associated unrest at the Vatukoula goldmine in Fiji, which is owned by the Emperor goldmining company. Emperor is not a subsidiary of the Western Mining Corporation, which withdrew earlier this year from joint venture ownership of the mine with Emperor. However, it does retain a management contract for the Vatukoula mine for a period of three years. I can confirm, on the basis of advice received from the Australian Embassy in Suva, that the strike is a result of a dispute over allegations of racism and complaints about safety and living conditions, pay and union recognition- so it has a number of different strands. I am advised that approximately 500 workers are currently on strike demanding recognition of the Fiji Mineworkers Union and improved pay and conditions.

ANSWER.PARA: The strike organised by that union is aimed primarily at securing employer recognition of the union. The union claims to have a membership of at least half of the workers, as required under law to ensure recognition, but management claims it does not, as compulsory recognition could be achieved through the Fiji Ministry of Labour if it did, without resort to such strike action. I have been aware of workers' grievances at the Emperor goldmine since early last year when I sought information about the situation from the Chairman of Western Mining. At that time, as I have said, Western Mining was still a major partner in the mine joint venture. My information is that wages at the mine are set in accordance with Fiji Government guidelines, and that other industrial disputes have been the subject of continuing discussion between the union and management at the mine. Essentially, the matter of employment conditions at the mine is one for the union, the mine owners and managers and the Fiji Government to consider.

The Embassy in Suva is following the situation closely because it is a major issue in Fiji at the moment, but for us to do any more in this case would not, I think, be particularly appropriate, given WMC's very significantly reduced role, nor do I think it would be potentially very helpful in terms of achieving any progress in the industrial dispute. Indeed, any very heavy-handed representations by us could risk a counterproductive response from the authorities in Fiji. Naturally, we continue to have a real concern, as we do on a universal basis, for workers' rights, but on balance this would not seem to be the kind of case where we could usefully do anything more than keep ourselves closely informed of developments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the Minister's comments on the weekend that we may be faced with a rolling recession, does he rule out the possibility that unemployment may rise above 10 per cent?

—I have said on previous occasions in the Senate that I think that unlikely. I suppose that is the answer to the question but, as the question is slightly more elaborate than that, let me say that how regularly or irregularly we come out of the recession is uncertain at the moment. My expectations are that most sectors of the economy will begin to emerge gradually from the recession in the latter half of this calendar year. If that is so, I repeat the answer I gave to the second part of the question, which relates to employment.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In view of the fact that the Treasurer has said that this recession has been planned by the Government, is the Minister asking us to believe that no thought was given to the level of unemployment which may result from the Government's planned recession?
—I am not asking Senator Kemp or anybody else to believe that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the failure to appoint anyone to the vacant chair of the Australia Council been deliberate Government policy? Is it because of a shortage of distinguished Australians prepared to work with this Government; is it simply that the Minister is incompetent; or is the Minister waiting, in line with her jobs for the boys approach in appointing the previous Deputy Prime Minister as Chairman of the Australian National Gallery, for the present and discredited Deputy Prime Minister to resign so that she can appoint him to the widely hawked and now discredited chair of the Australia Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume has asked some weird questions at times; that one, however, takes all the prizes. Quite obviously there is a lot of interest in who will become the Chairman of the Australia Council. The Minister, David Simmons, is the one who I think is taking the prime responsibility for it, not his senior Minister, Mrs Kelly. I believe that the matter will be discussed in Cabinet within the next few days, and we will have a recommendation from the Minister and, no doubt, a result. ANSWER.PARA: As far as no-one wanting to do the job is concerned, that is an assertion that the honourable senator knows to be false. TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of the extension or otherwise of Townsville Airport is a matter of which I am not fully apprised. I will have the facts of the matter checked and get a response for Senator Macdonald.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I ask: will the Minister advise the Senate of the countries with which Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement? What form does that agreement take? In relation to repatriation to homeland in the case of acute illness or death, what is available to those people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia currently has operational reciprocal health care agreements with a number of countries: the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Malta, Italy and Sweden. I know that negotiations are being undertaken with a number of other countries. Under these agreements, short term visitors or non-residents have access to the host country's public health care system as public patients on the same basis as residents of that country. That is very useful, of course, in a situation of an acute illness, where one needs treatment immediately for the onset of some disease or when some terrible accident has occurred. These arrangements do not extend coverage to prearranged or elective treatment. Likewise, treatment received through the private sector, including treatment as a private in-patient of a hospital, is not covered by these agreements. These reciprocal health care agreements cover all necessary medical, paramedical or hospital treatment to the extent that such treatment is provided under the host country's public health care system, but they do not include repatriation costs.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the point of Senator Jones's question probably is to say to those Australians visiting countries other than the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Malta, Italy or Sweden that they would be strongly advised to purchase a comprehensive travel insurance package which includes an adequate health cover component in order to deal with the very considerable health care costs that can accrue, particularly if they have hospital treatment in a country such as the United States of America. It is essential that that insurance be taken out as part of their travel plans.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I ask: what arrangements have been made for the 33 Indo-Chinese boat people and the 35 Cambodians who arrived in Darwin on separate vessels last week? What is the status of the other 220 Cambodian boat people who have been under detention since arriving in northern Australia in 1989 and 1990, particularly in light of the comments of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade last June that many of them would be unlikely to satisfy political refugee criteria. Has the Federal Government deliberately delayed processing claims because of the difficulty in arranging return for people who fail to satisfy such criteria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some information in respect of at least the 33 Indo-Chinese and 35 Cambodians who have arrived in Australia. As Senator Tambling mentioned, the boat with 35 Cambodians on board arrived in Darwin harbour on 6 March. Twenty-five of these have already been transferred to accommodation in Sydney and Melbourne. The persons on the vessel identified themselves as Cambodians. The vessel was escorted into Darwin harbour late on the evening of 6 March. The available details correspond with those in recent press reports of a boat load of 35 Cambodians heading for Australia. There were 19 adults, and 16 children under the age of 18. All aboard appeared to be in good health. However, there were two pregnant women on board and they were taken to hospital as a precautionary measure. The group states that it left the Cambodian port city of Kompong Som on 21 January and spent some time in Indonesia en route. Assuming that the boat is Cambodian, it will be the fourth boat from Cambodia to reach Australia, the first three having arrived in November 1989, March 1990 and June 1990. I am informed that there are no further boats on the way.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have mentioned, 25 of these people were flown south on 7 March to accommodation in Sydney and Melbourne. This was due to a shortage of suitable accommodation in the Darwin area. Eighteen of them are in Melbourne and seven in Sydney for the initial processing period. The remaining 10 will stay in Darwin for the time being. Five are being detained for further questioning and the other five are a family group obliged to stay behind because of the wife's advanced stage of pregnancy. I am informed that the entire group of 35 should be collocated later in either Melbourne or Sydney.

The Minister has informed me that it is of real concern to him that the people who undertake these hazardous sea voyages reach Australia. His concern is compounded in that people who are seeking asylum choose to pass through other countries on the way without claiming protection. This does cause another problem. People seeking asylum are searching for protection that they do not believe their own country affords them and are not setting out for a preferred destination in which to settle.

About 224 direct boat arrivals from Cambodia are already in Australia. I think that Senator Tambling mentioned 220. In the main they have not yet finalised their refugee applications. I reject the allegations as to why that has happened. I am informed that, although the Sydney and Melbourne groups had lodged applications, they sought to revise them. So far only 14 applications from the Melbourne group have since been relodged. Those in the Darwin group have yet to lodge their applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister failed to appreciate the importance of the second part of my question which related to the processing of 220 refugees since 1989 and 1990 and their ability to satisfy the political refugee criteria. I was seeking to ascertain the reason for the government processing of these claims and whether this is dependent upon the failure to negotiate arrangements for the return of these people.

—I probably do need to restate the position for Senator Tambling. My information is that in the main the 224 arrivals from Cambodia already in Australia have not yet finalised their refugee applications. I further went on to say that, although the Sydney and Melbourne groups have lodged applications, they have sought to revise them. So far only 14 applications from the Melbourne group have been relodged. If there is any further information that I can usefully provide, I will do so.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Did the Minister's answer to the question asked by my colleague Senator Kemp as to whether the Government had considered unemployment figures rising to or beyond 10 per cent amount to Senator Button disowning the Treasurer's claim that this Government had planned and, indeed, engineered this recession which, according to the same Treasurer, is the recession that we had to have?

—No, it did not amount to that at all. I was asked whether I thought unemployment would rise above 10 per cent. In essence, I said that I did not believe so but I did not know. As I have said in answer to a number of questions in Question Time today, Senator Bishop will appreciate, these things are uncertain in terms of the time of recovery of the Australian economy. There is nobody with a definitive view about it. Anybody who had a definitive view would be taking a very chancy view of the world.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand the air of despondency which the Government is displaying today with the industry statement about to come down tomorrow and no doubt it will be the failure that it will be. I wonder whether Senator Button would tell us once and for all: did this Government plan the recession or did it not?

—A number of statements have been made by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer in relation to this matter. Had Senator Bishop been listening over the past two years, she would have heard her colleagues ask a number of questions about the high levels of interest rates, and the answers given by various Ministers. The point is that the Government, faced with a very high rate of growth in the Australian economy in late 1988 and 1989, sought to dampen that level of growth which led to a huge influx of imports to this country. That was the strategy which the Government talked about again and again in answer to opportunistic questions about interest rates from the Opposition.
—So the answer is yes.

—Senator Bishop should not interrupt me. If she is interested in the answer, rather than perform, she should listen. It is quite clear that the Government sought to dampen the rate of growth in the Australian economy.
—Did you succeed?

—The answer is yes. Both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer made comments to the effect that maybe we kept the brakes on a little too long. That has been said publicly and there is no retreating from that position. In terms of planning unemployment, which is the implication of Senator Bishop's first question-unemployment was one of the most lagged things in the indicators which were available to the Government in the calendar year 1990 and which made it quite distinct from the 1982 recession when unemployment grew much more rapidly and to a much greater extent.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I draw the Minister's attention to the reported danger to the environment from the burning of the Kuwaiti Greater Burgan oil fields, one of the world's largest oil fields, where almost all of the 654 oil wells were set alight by the Iraqis. Is the Minister aware of any estimate of time in which the fires are likely to be contained, and could he inform the Senate of what action is being taken to contain the fires? Is there any evidence available that the smog and pollutant gases can be contained within the region?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order to note that Senator Jones is asking a question for the third time in the Senate today when many senators have not asked a question. Is there no other member of the Government that has a question to put to Ministers today?
—Order! There is no point of order. That sort of point of order, I believe, is deliberately disorderly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be last week's question but it is still this week's problem, and it might be a problem for a good many months and indeed years yet. As such, I think it is important that the Senate understand the dimension of it. I think all of us know the circumstances in which the fires have been caused in Kuwait-the immense program of destruction that the Iraqis embarked upon in the course of their retreat. The scale of the damage that has been caused is beginning only now to be appreciated.

ANSWER.PARA: Our own ambassador to Saudi Arabia and Kuwait visited Kuwait just a few days ago. In his report he referred to the extraordinary pollution being caused and tangibly feelable by a visitor-the extensive smoke pall, the strong smell of burning oil, the oily feel to the rain; and he said that, generally, with the darkness and the cold, it was as if being in Kuwait was being in a northern European city in the depths of winter. These are merely impressionistic observations, of course.

The concern is that the damage is going to be very real indeed. Fires are burning at least three million barrels of oil per day and, according to Japan's environment agency, producing smoke containing 35,000 tonnes of sulphur dioxide per day. The smoke could cause the temperature in the Gulf region to cool up to five degrees. The cloud has spread over Bahrain, Qatar, south-western Iran and part of Iraq. It is not expected at this stage to affect the broader region in the sense that predictions of environmental damage to the Indian subcontinent have been premised on 10 million barrels of oil burning each day rather than the three million that represents the current estimate.

As to the prospects for putting these fires out, it is going to take up to two months alone to clear the area of mines before fire fighters can move in. Then the task ahead is manifestly enormous. Current estimates are of the order of two years or more to put out the fires. There have never been so many oil fires burning at once, and their extinguishment even by the expert resources now being flown in from all around the world will manifestly be an enormous task.

BALTIC COMMITTEE
153 Jesmond Rd. Indooroopilly Qld 4068 Tel: (07) 378 0319
BALTIC INDEPENDENCE RALLY- 9 MARCH 1991 BRISBANE: RESOLUTIONS

On 9 February and 3 March 1991 residents of the Republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia participated in an `advisory vote' on the proposition: `Do you support a democratic and independent statehood for the Republic?'. More than 70% of the voters in each Republic supported this statement. Following these convincing independence plebiscites, we ask the Australian government for a formal, authoritative statement in reference to the renewal of the independence of the Baltic states which could include the following actions:

1. Establish de facto recognition of the elected governments in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania by sending diplomatic and government representatives to the Baltic states and receiving Baltic diplomats and government representatives in a manner befitting the opening of relations between sovereign governments.

2. Establish Australian information centres in the Baltic states and support the establishment of Baltic information centres in Australia. Such an exchange of information centres-already implemented by Sweden, Denmark and Belgium-would serve as the foundation for formal diplomatic missions in the future.

3. Make aid available directly to the people of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. The major need is for technical and educational assistance in repairing damage to the environment, rebuilding economic and government infrastructure and renewing social services.

4. Inform the USSR explicitly that the Baltic states issue is not for the USSR to deal with alone, but is a matter of international concern-the last unresolved issue from World War II. The Baltic states did not join the USSR of their own free will. The renewal of Baltic independence should be raised in all available international forums, particularly in the United Nations.
5. Persuade the USSR to enter into good-faith negotiations with the governments of the Baltic states, to end Soviet occupation and to renew their independence.
6. Express dissatisfaction to the USSR, and discontinue aid to the Soviet central government, if it avoids meaningful negotiations or encourages armed intervention in the Baltic states.

We feel that a firm stand must be taken to support the wish for independence of the majority of people in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. Such a stand, under the auspices of the United Nations, has successfully restored an independent Kuwait. Concerted international action is now necessary to achieve peaceful resolution of the Baltic states independence issue.
Dr. Arnis Siksna
Chairman, Baltic Committee of Queensland.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE FAMILY LAW ACT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a joint select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, be appointed to inquire into and report on the provisions and operation of the Family Law Act 1975 and, where the committee thinks appropriate and necessary, make such recommendations for amendments to the Family Law Act and other action in respect of:
(a) the role, funding, effectiveness and availability of the services of:
(i) the Family Court Counselling Service, and
(ii) approved organisations providing marriage counselling and family mediation services;
(b) the proper resolution of custody, guardianship, welfare and access disputes;

(c) the proper resolution of family law property disputes, including the question whether it is desirable that the Family Law Act be extended to property disputes arising out of de facto relationships;
(d) the effective enforcement of rights and duties under the Family Law Act;

(e) the exercise of discretion by the courts, including the question whether it is desirable to better structure the exercise of the discretion of the courts in making orders determining disputes in relation to children or property;

(f) the adversarial nature of proceedings under the Family Law Act and their associated legal costs, including the question whether amendments to the Act or other action are desirable to require or encourage greater use of arbitration, mediation or other forms of alternative dispute resolution;
(g) the prohibition in the Family Law Act on the publication of accounts of proceedings which identify parties, witnesses or other persons associated with the proceedings; and
(h) the retiring age for judges of the Family Court of Australia.
(2) That in its inquiry the committee may at its discretion examine such previous enquiries, recommendations and evidence the committee thinks relevant.

(3) That the committee consist of 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority groups or independent Senators.
(4) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(5) That the committee elect a member nominated by the Government Whips or the Leader of the Government in the Senate as its chairman.

(6) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(7) That, in the event of the votes on a question before the committee being equally divided, the chairman, or the deputy chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.
(8) That 5 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(9) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(10) That the committee appoint the chairman of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only, and at any time when the chairman of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of a subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chairman at that meeting only.
(11) That the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the members of that subcommittee.

(12) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(13) That the committee and a subcommittee have power to send for persons and documents.

(14) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the Speaker.
(15) That the committee and a subcommittee have power to move from place to place, to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
(16) That the committee report to each House of the Parliament by the first sitting week in August 1992.
(17) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(18) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution be communicated by message to the House of Representatives with a request for the concurrence of that House in the resolution.

Mr Kevin O'Connor

Dear Senator Giles
I refer to your letter of 21 December 1990 raising certain concerns in relation to the public interest determination dated 29 October made under section 72 of the Privacy Act 1988.
(1) Tabling of second document:

As noted by the Committee the determination was tabled twice in the Senate. After the first document was tabled, the Senate Tabling Officer advised that it was not in order in one respect. He considered that the heading on page 10 needed to be amended to indicate that the determination was made under section 72 of the Privacy Act and because of that change, the date on page 11 also needed to be amended. These changes are incorporated in the second document tabled.
(2) Range of bodies and individuals consulted:

While the application and the concerns of the Director of Public Prosecutions in relation to disclosure for public service purposes focused on the needs of Commonwealth agencies, it was clear at the conference that the concerns applied equally to cases involving state public service bodies. In my view once an exception was given allowing disclosure to one set of public service bodies (Commonwealth agencies), it followed that the same standard should apply in relation to all public service bodies, whether Commonwealth, State or Territory. Otherwise the situation could arise where the Director of Public Prosecutions would have differing powers of disclosure in relation to a public servant, simply on the basis of whether he or she was a Commonwealth officer or not. Such a determination would I think have been viewed by many as illogical.

The Committee raises the question of the adequacy and degree of notice given. I have so far followed the practice of giving notice in The Australian newspaper because of its national circulation and in The Canberra Times because of the relevance to federal government of the applications. This practice was followed in the case of the application currently under consideration. I have been reluctant to advertise more widely-say in every major newspaper-because of cost considerations. The cost is high and borne by my budget. However, I would be happy to consider any Committee comments in that regard.

I have seen circulation to potentially interested bodies and organisations as a more effective and less costly way of giving notice. My office mails to individuals and organisations considered to have an interest in public interest determinations generally, a copy of the application. This list is regularly updated and expanded. I acknowledge that the circulation in this case could have possibly been wider and included a wide range of union groups. I will keep that concern in mind when dealing with any failure similar issues. But I shouild emphasise that circulations of this kind are at my discretion and not required by the Act.
(3) Scope of determination and notice:

It would appear that the Committee is particularly concerned about the inclusion of public service bodies in the final determination. The application from the Director of Public Prosecutions in fact did refer to the need for that office to be able to make disclosures to public service bodies. Individuals receiving a copy of the application would have been aware of the possible scope of the final determination.

I acknowledge that the public notice did not cover, expressly this element of the application. The notice sought to give the public a general indication of the nature of the application. Short of republishing the application in full, there will always be an element of judgment in how extensive the particulars given in the notice are. My aim at the time was to give a general indication of the scope of the application. In future, in light of the concerns, I will seek to be more specific, possibly confirming the notice with the applicant.

The clause which appeared in this public notice foreshadowing further possible notices no longer appears in determination notices. Our experience in this case was that further public notices proved not to be necessary. This determination was one of two initial public interest determinations and during the conduct of this determination procedures were being developed and refined. The final procedures while not precluding further notices have not stated that such notices are mandatory.
(4) Absence of list of organisations to whom disclosures may be made:

I explained in the reasons for the determination why a ``list'' approach would not be practical; and in that regard accepted the submission of the Director of Public Prosecutions. If the ``list'' approach had been adopted a new public interest determination process would have to be undertaken each time a change to the list was envisaged. There are nin Parliaments in Australia dealing regularly with the scope and structure of occupational discipline and regulation; as well as nine governments, through administrative arrangements and regulations. I do not see it as productive to invite a process which involves the need to continually seek amendment or variation of a list of approved recipients. What instead I sought to do in the determination was to impose procedural safeguards on the exercise of discretion by the Director of Public Prosecutions which would enable my office or anyone with a relevant concern to ascertain quickly whether the discretionwas being properly and reasonably exercised.
(5) Defining Permitted Recipients:
The three terms queried by the Committee (recipient agency; recipient of the information; and recipient) are synonymous. I will seek to avoid, in future, variations in terms of this kind.

``Permitted recipient'' and similar terms are intended to cover any body with the functions referred to in the primary clause of the determination. I would be happy to table a further amended determination to meet any concerns in relation to lack of explicit reference to who is entitled to receive the information. I would propose the inclusion of the words ``to a body which has the relevant regulatory or disciplinary function'' after the word ``disclosure'' in line 3. An alternative to taking this step might be to obtain a written undertaking from the Director of Public Prosecutions that the determination will be applied in that way.
(6) Impact of the determination:

Your letter also raised the question of the number of agencies affected. The Director of Public Prosecutions was not able to provide a detailed list of bodies affected. However, the Director did provide examples, as mentioned in the determination, indicating the range of bodies covered. It should also be kept in mind that although the possible number of organisations may be large, the number to whom the Director releases information in any one year is quite small, estimated by the Director's office to be no more than 10. In addition the determination provides for a monitoring role in which the Director must, annually, provide me with a list of disclosures made.

I welcome the oversight and comment of the Committee and hope that the above advice addresses your concerns regarding the procedures followed in relation to public interest determination number 2. If I can be of further assistance please do not hesitate to contact me.
