TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 11 March, from Senator Coulter:

INTERJECT.PARA: Today I shall move that, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
`The need to establish a pattern of ecologically sustainable development of the forest products industry requiring the Federal Government to:
(a) ensure that nearly all of Australia's sawn timber requirements are met from plantations by the year 2000;
(b) phase out export woodchipping of native forests by 1995, and;
(c) increase value-adding in the pulp and paper industry through an import replacement strategy based on moderate scale, chlorine-free pulp mills fed from hardwood plantations and recycled paper.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency motion we are debating today seeks the Senate's endorsement of an ecologically sustainable development strategy for the forestry and forest products industry. It calls on the Hawke Government to phase out the economic and environmental vandalism that is decimating our native forests and has left us with an enormous trade deficit in pulp and paper products.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter is indeed urgent because the Government, far from encouraging a shift to a sustainable strategy, is poised to lock this country for the next 10 to 15 years into the discredited practices of the past-under pressure from an industry which refuses to face the fact that it has to change in order to survive. By agreeing to enact resource security legislation, Cabinet has ensured that the 1990s will be a lost decade for the forests, and for the forestry and the forest products industry. The spectacular growth in plantations and the burgeoning interest in recycling are presenting the Government with a golden opportunity to restructure the industry for the long term benefit of this nation.

Surely with the Government's industry statement about to be tabled tomorrow, this is a time when we should be looking for such opportunities. That the Government has rejected this opportunity is testimony to its failure of vision, and its panic response to the blackmail tactics of industry groups which are exploiting the recession to get their hands on as much of the nation's ecological capital as they can before the market collapses altogether and turns against them.

Cabinet Ministers have tried to defend their decision by claiming that assessments will still be made under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and the Australian Heritage Commission Act before resource security legislation is put in place, and that section 30 of the Heritage Commission Act will only be overridden after that point. According to newspaper reports, Cabinet is exploring mechanisms to ensure that any rare or endangered species found to be threatened by logging can still be protected by providing alternative supplies. How naive does the Government think we are?

These assurances are hollow for three fundamental reasons. First, our knowledge of the ecological value of many of our forest zones is sketchy. The Government's own environmental databases, the national forest inventory and the national wilderness inventory, are far from being completed. Once timber companies gain access to vast tracts of publicly owned native forests, there is nothing to prevent them from deliberately-and I stress deliberately-logging areas of potential ecological value before they have been fully evaluated. I pose the rhetorical question, Mr Acting Deputy President: what would you do if you had invested a large sum of money, in excess of $100m, and found a rare species in part of your concession which would perhaps prevent you from continuing to exploit that concession?

Secondly, there is far too little knowledge about the impact of logging on the natural values of forests. Mr Justice Stewart, Chairman of the Resource Assessment Commission, recently observed in answer to a question at the National Press Club:
The vital question is, is there enough timber to guarantee resource security? Let me tell you quite frankly that no-one, but no-one knows the answer yet.

Justice Stewart's views were echoed in last Saturday's Canberra Times by Philip Smiles. I stress for the benefit of Opposition senators that I am referring to Philip Smiles, the Liberal member for Mosman in the New South Wales Parliament and Chair of the Public Accounts Committee in that State, which recently released a damning report on the New South Wales Forestry Commission. Mr Smiles was quoted as saying:
Until we come to a realistic estimation of what sustainable yields mean in each locality, we cannot talk about resource security.

In other words, Mr Smiles, a member of the Liberal Government in New South Wales, is rejecting, at least at this stage, the idea of resource security. The Federal Government simply cannot simultaneously claim to be providing resource security and protecting the environment when no-one knows what a sustainable yield is and, moreover, when no-one knows what the values are in the forest which need to be sustained. I am referring to the values beyond simply the values of the timber. Thirdly, it is quite obvious that logging our forests causes more ecological damage than logging plantations on previously cleared land. But if the Government clings to the outdated and, I stress, incorrect view that plantations cannot supplant native forests over the next decade, then it will simply accept the environmental damage and loss of national estate forests as a regrettable necessity.

It is in this context that the plan to override section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act assumes great significance. Until now, section 30 has allowed the Government to regularly examine and re-examine whether prudent and feasible alternatives exist before authorising further logging of a national estate forest. Under resource security legislation, that circuit-breaker will be lost. Within a short time-and I am referring to the next five to 10 years-the Federal Government will belatedly discover that Australia's timber demand can be met largely from plantations and that the export woodchip market will increasingly be supplied from eucalypt plantations in other countries. It will then regret having signed away its powers to redirect the industry to meet these challenges and to preserve our environmental heritage. It will instead be stuck with an agreement which will become increasingly expensive to honour. It is this failure to read the writing on the economic wall that particularly concerns the Australian Democrats.

The Government would do particularly well to examine the work of Judy Clark, an economist and timber industry consultant, who studied the domestic and international markets in forest products. In a speech to the Australian Conservation Foundation forum, Ms Clark identified a number of key trends. First, maturing pine plantations will produce enough timber to meet most of Australia's sawn timber needs by the year 2000, assuming demand growth. Presently, it supplies some 45 per cent of our sawlogs. Secondly, New Zealand pine is entering our market at close to Australian production costs. New Zealand will shortly have sufficient capacity to meet both its own and Australia's sawn timber needs. This will force Australian plantations to be brought into production as early as possible to maintain competitiveness.

Thirdly, State forestry commissions will come under increasing pressure to lift their financial performance, resulting in price increases for native forest logs. Fourthly, hardwood sawlog quality is declining, affecting economic viability. Indeed, only some 5 per cent of logs now being taken go into sawlog and many are then sent straight to the chippers. This factor is behind the demise of the sawmilling industry and the disastrous slide into export woodchipping of native forests.

Fifthly, regrowth forests are unlikely to be able to supply large scale sawmilling developments. Sixthly, the world's supply of hardwood chips will change dramatically over the next three to seven years, as, I stress, seven million hectares of eucalypt plantations come on stream in Brazil, South Africa, Portugal and Spain. These plantations will produce enough timber to supply Japan's woodchip demand 10 times over, dwarfing Australia's output. Indeed, Australia will be able to supply some 5 per cent of the world market.

Seventhly, Australian demand for fibre to meet our projected paper consumption could be met without logging native forests by the year 2000, by relying instead on hardwood and softwood plantations and recycled paper. By the mid-1990s four Australian companies will have enough hardwood plantation resources to feed medium scale pulp and paper mills.

Miss Clark concludes that native forests will almost cease to supply the domestic sawlog market by the year 2000, with softwood plantations taking over the market. Small, labour intensive hardwood sawmills producing high quality products will remain competitive. Many other mills will close, continuing the present trend. The export market for Australian woodchips, pulp and paper is likely to decline rapidly throughout this decade.

If the Government pursues its present export oriented development strategy, the Australian economy will be vulnerable to this shrinking market. We could well be left with a number of world-class pulp mills which are unable to earn enough to pay off the foreign loans which finance them. What will the subsidy be then on developments undertaken behind the guarantee of resource security? A strategy of replacing imports and seeking niche export markets for paper products offers less risk.

The upshot of this analysis is that logging of native forests is an activity whose days are numbered. It is being kept alive only because plantation resources that will soon drive native forest hardwoods from the market are still maturing, and because it is being subsidised by low royalties and underpricing.

The New South Wales Public Accounts Committee report on the Forestry Commission of New South Wales demonstrates this point. That is the report to which I referred earlier. The Committee found that native forest timbers were being underpriced by the Commission, which was, in the words of this report, `bloated, inward looking, poorly managed and provoked needless confrontation with environmentalists'. Conversely, the Commission had depressed some parts of the market for pine logs by overpricing. It has paid no dividend-I stress: no dividend-to the New South Wales Treasury. The Public Accounts Committee recommends real price increases for native forest pulp logs.

Nor is this problem confined to New South Wales. I turn to Tasmania, where the question of resource security will loom somewhat larger, perhaps, in the weeks ahead. The Tasmanian Forestry Commission has outstanding debts of more than-wait for it, Mr Acting Deputy President-$450m; an operating deficit of $20m a year; and has failed to pay a dividend to Consolidated Revenue since 1926.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the assets?

—The State Government has tried to conceal some of the Commission's debt by taking out equity in its own forests, thus transferring the debt to the Treasury. The Auditor-General has responded to this mess by accusing the Commission of using unsound accounting practices in its 1989-90 annual report. I am glad that Senator Walters interjected, because the value placed on the Tasmanian Forestry Commission is zero.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the economically mismanaged, publicly subsidised industry into whose hands the present Government proposes to entrust our remaining native forests, with no real prospect of recall. This is an industry which not only is not ecologically sustainable, but also is not yet within a cooee of achieving economic sustainability. There is a crying need for a major overhaul of the forestry and forest products industry in Australia. One of the results of a thorough shake-out would be to force native forest logging to compete on a level playing field with plantations. Instead, the Federal Government is determined to entrench the bad practices of the past by opening up our native forests to accelerated and guaranteed destruction.

The push for resource security is an attempt by the forestry industry to rip as much timber as possible out of our native forests before market trends and public opinion turn against it. A quote from the Private Forestry Council of Tasmania-part of the industry itself-made in only 1990, just last year, illustrates this thinking. It reads as follows:

It is imperative that as much of the remaining private old-growth pulpwood resource as is available for sale is marketed over the next 15 years whilst market acceptance of this comparatively low commercial quality wood is relatively high. Quota restrictions on the harvesting of this resource must be lifted immediately.

There one has it in a nutshell. The pressure from the industry is to move in on this resource, rip it out-recognising that it is of low value at this time but that there will be a market for it over the next 10 to 15 years-and destroy it, and the market will then collapse.

If the Federal Government is serious about pursuing an appropriate development strategy for the industry, it must take a long, hard look at the economic prognosis for the forestry and forest products industry and come up with a strategy that is environmentally and economically sustainable. In particular, the work of Judy Clark, to which I referred earlier, and the Australian Conservation Foundation, while not purporting to provide definitive answers to this question, deserves close attention. It is precisely for this reason that the Federal Government initiated the Resource Assessment Commission's inquiry into the industry. The Commission's task is to make recommendations consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. It has been specifically asked to look at the Conservation Foundation's strategy in reaching its conclusions. But the Government has now decided on a long term strategy before the Commission's reported deadline at the end of this year.
Earlier this year Mr Justice Stewart made it clear to the National Press Club that he would not welcome such a move. He said:

While our enquiries are going on . . . the Government [does not] cease to govern . . . but what could impact on [the Commission's] enquiry is that the Government purports to take a decision which is irreversible.
The Government has made a decision which appears irreversible. I refer again to what Phillip Smiles, a Liberal member in the New South Wales Government, has said:
The Australian taxpayer is entitled to demand that the Commission not be sidelined in this way.

The resource security fiasco is a sign of panic. It has nothing to do with environmental protection. It is not based on any comprehensive long term economic vision. It is a kneejerk response to the political blackmail of an industry which needs for its own sake to be hauled, screaming, into the 1990s by resolute Government action. Instead, it has been given permission to protect itself from today's political, economic and environmental realities.

It is noteworthy that only one Cabinet Minister strongly believes that resource security is necessary and desirable. Media reports state that Ministers Keating, Richardson, Beazley, Kelly and Hand opposed it in Cabinet. Minister Kerin supported it even while believing that it should not be necessary. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stated publicly only a few weeks ago that it was not necessary but decided to support it to satisfy industry demands. Only Senator Button is a passionate advocate of the legislation, as he is with other cargo cult myths such as the multifunction polis. The Government has ceased to govern according to its own convictions. It is now being driven by industry forces in a pragmatic way acting against the public interest. It is a matter of urgency that the Government take charge and plan for an ecologically sustainable economic future. It is for that reason that I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by refuting the concluding remarks of Senator Coulter. Senator Coulter has premised this so-called urgency motion upon rumour, speculation, innuendo and press reporting. He has fabricated an argument based on that, knowing full well that in about 24 hours the Government will be putting down, both in the House of Representatives and in this chamber, a statement on industry policy in which it will say precisely and absolutely what its position is on the question of resource security.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter has been proposed by the Australian Democrats for debate by the Senate without their knowing what it is that the Government will say, but with their believing the speculation, rumour, innuendo and reporting in the press. Therefore, the whole premise of this debate is wrong and it is, indeed, promoted to obscure responsible argument, considered analysis and dispassionate and objective analysis of the real issues that the Government stands for. When we have views presented on where particular Government Ministers stand in the privacy of the Cabinet debate as though they are true, I must say that I am offended. Those comments are really based on hearsay and they have nothing at all to do with the truth. The Government is united on this issue. Tomorrow the Government will say what it proposes and we will then invite debate. Let the debate be about the facts. Let the debate not be about assumptions.

In my contribution today, I want to start on a definitional note. Last week-I think it was Wednesday-Mr Chaney, in one those rare displays from him as the shadow Minister for the environment, asked a question of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the House of Representatives on resource security. In the ensuing few minutes there was an argument within the House that has become somewhat notorious since then. What was displayed during that argument-and which Hansard, to some extent, reveals-was that the mask of the Opposition has slipped on environmental matters; some of the unguarded comments in the heat of battle in the House reveal an extraordinary attitude of resentment towards the environment or environmental organisations and spokesmen in Australia. That is not at all surprising. One has only to ask any member of the National Party of Australia-none of whom, I notice, are taking part in this debate-to see that there is in this country an extremely wide chasm between the major political parties, the only parties that can form a government, as to where they stand on matters of the environment.

Mr Chaney is a case in point. As spokesman on the environment, many of his remarks are led by comments such as, `We must do more', `We must look further at that' and `I am interested in this'. He refers in his comments to land degradation, biodiversity and ecologically sustainable development. Indeed, in June 1990, he said, `Sounding green is a bit easy'. What we have from the Opposition is a collection of phrases going nowhere, being unspecific, not explaining an Opposition alternative and giving voters in this country no chance to judge the contrast of the competing policies of the Government and the Opposition, which aspires to government. In this country there is a huge political chasm between both parties. The Opposition is all talk, no substance. When pushed, it generalises; it sounds sympathetic and it never makes a commitment. That is the position of the Opposition.

In fact and in reality this is a green government and one that is not an anti-environment government. We are recognised as that. We recognise and take seriously our responsibilities in this country for development and economic management. We have a process to reconcile what in the 1990s and the next century will remain as one of the thorniest questions in world politics: we have a policy to deal with the conflict between protecting the environment and aspiring as a community to better environmental standards and at the same time maintaining economic development to assure the citizens of this country a standard of living to which they too equally aspire, with no particular contradiction in terms of their demands in respect of the environment and of a secure, safe and high standard of living.

We have a policy for ecologically sustainable development. We have a process by which we can implement that. We see a desirable outcome in this debate as being a win-win outcome so that both development and the environment are brought into a convergence, not into opposition, so that we can manage intelligently the art of meshing those two objectives. The Opposition, for its part, has a win-lose mentality. It slips back into the rhetoric of the 1950s. It talks as though nothing has changed.

I conclude my definitional point by saying that, in terms of the parties which aspire to government in this country, there is a clear contrast between the Government and the Opposition which is unassailable. We have a responsible policy; we are going about implementing it. It is a policy for ecologically sustainable development that tries intelligently to mesh the important environmental considerations and those of growth and development. It is an art which we do not always get perfectly right, but an art which, since we are a consultative government, not a confrontationist government, we are bound to follow, with the support of the social partners in our society.

With those words, I turn to the motion of the Australian Democrats. I do not, in the beginning, question the sincerity of the Democrats because they have been consistent in their views on the environment at all points. But they are not, if I might say this, a party that aspires to government. They are a party which can afford to be all care and no responsibility on a matter such as this. Whatever the Government does, they can always say that it has not gone far enough. Whatever the Government proposes about industry development, they can always say that it can be dealt with some other way, without specifying how it can be dealt with and how workers' jobs in this country can be protected without their being lost unnecessarily in a situation such as this.

The Democrats are in a perfect position-what Americans would call the catbird seat-in terms of this debate. Whatever anyone does, they say that they can do it better, they can do it further, they can do more of it and they can do it in a more fulsome and more rounded way.

That is not responsibility in government. That is not having to front up every day for the hard decisions. Nonetheless, as I have said, despite that many of the things that the Australian Democrats say are trite and superficial, I believe they are passionate in their convictions about them.

I now turn to the issue. As I have said, I cannot, as the Democrats know, defend myself in this debate by resorting to the facts. I cannot do that because the facts will be announced by the Government tomorrow. I will not be sucked in by the invitation to speculate on or announce prematurely what the Government intends to say tomorrow. That is not appropriate or responsible government. So I say to the Democrats, who have based so much of what they put here on the newspapers, speculation, rumour and innuendo, that they should have waited until tomorrow.

Some of those in my own Party who have gone public on this matter have been at least courageous enough to admit that they were mistaken. I particularly acknowledge the public comments by Senator James McKiernan, on my side of politics, who was associated within the factional system of the Labor Party with a resolution calling on the Government to change its course. But when, in the consultative way in which we go about managing our affairs, Senator McKiernan learnt more about what it was that the Government proposed to do, he said publicly and honestly that he had reason, therefore, to change his view. If a man of infinite integrity such as Senator McKiernan can be misled into joining a public clamour and then, when confronted with evidence, say, `Well, I was wrong; I must now change my position', I hope that many more in the Australian community will wait until the facts of the statement come forward so that they can see what is intended. I think that many more will then change their position too.

With those words, I go to the question that is fundamental to many of these things. It could be said that, following the all care, no responsibility route of the Democrats, at best their motion today is idealistic, if not practical. That is a reasonable and respectable thing to do. It does not necessarily mean that all idealists have to be practical. It does mean that governments have to be, but idealists do not have to be. We have to mesh both.

If one were a harsh critic of the Democrats' motive in proposing impossible tests to fulfil, one could see in this motion a mask for destroying an industry central to the Australian economy. This motion proposes to do things by the year 2000 which are not capable of being done. It proposes that we should obtain the vast bulk of our wood supply from plantations. That is something to which this Government aspires. However, as the fastest growing eucalypt for Australian hardwoods is the Tasmanian blue gum, and as it takes 15 years to get to a level where it is pulpable for paper manufacture-not sawable for plank timber-even if we started today, the question of how we would achieve self-sufficiency out of plantations in nine years is indeed a practical question to ask.

There are a number of other elements of this. If the worst case is true and this motion is a mask for destruction, I think it does raise a fundamental question of morality-one that has plagued me in this timber debate for the years that I have followed it. This is the moral question as I see it: the Australian timber industry is an industry which cannot supply its own domestic market. It is an industry in which we import more than we provide for our own needs. In terms of imports, timber represents about 10 per cent of the current account deficit. We buy timber from other countries. Imports have increased by 120 per cent since 1983-84.

Since this Government came to power, by following the course of demanding responsibility in forest management by the States-given that we ourselves do not have the constitutional head of power; it is a State responsibility-and by using our export control powers to ensure that they manage their forest resources better, there has been a blowout in terms of the amount of imported timber in this country. We do not apologise for that. We say that that is a necessary recognition of harsher, better, more stringent, environmental controls in the management of what is a rare and unique Australian resource. So, we do not resile from that.

But if a sensible way of cutting and managing those forests is not provided, how do we curtail the thirst that this developed country has for the consumption of paper and timber products? This is where the question of morality comes in. It means that the responsibility for supplying the market is pushed offshore and onto Third World countries-onto the shoulders to the Penan people in Sarawak, onto the shoulders of pirate loggers in the forests of Indonesia, onto the shoulders of people who were so excessive in the exploitation of native forests in Thailand that the then democratically elected government, now disposed by a military dictatorship, closed down forestry development to allow its forests to regrow.

The moral questions are whether we should manage our forests in this country in accordance with ecologically sustainable development, taking care of biodiversity, taking care of rare and endangered species and taking care of proper, sensible, environment development in a way in which we can meet demands that are reasonable of our timber industry; whether we should develop a plantation strategy alongside that so that so that we can shift our primary reliance on native forests into plantations; whether we should learn how better to utilise the resource so that we take more from the forest floor than we used to burn; and whether we should learn better cutting techniques so that the same volume of resource goes further and is used more wisely.

Should we do all of those things rather than think we are achieving something by asking that our forests not be touched and be held as some antique museum for posterity, thereby pushing the demand that this community unquestionably has onto the Third World and acquiesce in the poor management practices that those countries unfortunately have? It seems to me that that is the challenge. Unless the Australian Democrats can come forward and ask us how we can manage to do that, the more this industry will be closed down. Without doing something about demand, the more we acquiesce in the rape of tropical forests in our near north.
With those words, I now turn to the provisions of this motion. The motion asks the Government to:
ensure that nearly all of Australia's sawn timber requirements are met from plantations from the year 2000;

As I have said, the fastest growing Australian eucalypt is the Tasmanian blue gum. If one were planted tomorrow in proper environmental, weather, soil and fertiliser conditions, it would take 15 years to get to a level at which it could be pulped, not sawn for plank timber. I ask the Democrats: how can they expect a government to support a motion which defies the biological growth rates of the fastest growing tree by some six years? The Democrats ask us to do it in nine years. We point out to the Democrats that it can only be done in 15 years.

Of course, the Democrats ignore the fact that we have a strategy to convert more of our demand to plantations. We have a strategy to encourage Australian farmers to grow Australian eucalypts on unfertile or little used parts of their farms at a guaranteed buy-back rate so that they have, if you like, a cash crop which weans the industry's demands off native forests. Farmers can utilise sections of their land for this purpose.

We have a strategy which promotes broad acre plantation cultivation in Australia and a number of experimental and commercial farms are now in existence. We have a strategy for better management of regrowth forests. It seems to us that by better management of those forests we may in fact get a higher yield for commercial timber resources and thus not need the high capital expenditure of acquiring land and developing the broad acre proposal. So, in terms of the utility of the first proposition, I say that it has no practical application to reality. It does not recognise the trends or the changes and it is, therefore, pie in the sky.

Secondly, the Democrats ask us to phase out woodchipping by the year 1995. I would like to phase out woodchipping in Australia today. That is what I would like to do. It is a waste of a rare national resource, in my view. But the way in which it should be phased out should be to turn it not into chips but into pulp or paper to go up the value-added developmental route. The only way that can be done is to have investment in companies that will turn it into pulp and paper.

There is nothing in this motion that suggests how we will attract investment if there is not a security in some form or other-a properly guarded, a properly hedged, a properly balanced and a properly managed security-to ensure that there is a supply of resource. Which entrepreneur will put in millions of dollars to develop the turning of chips into pulp and paper if there is not some form of security such as that? The Democrats do not recognise those practical questions when they talk about the phase out of woodchips by 1995-unless they want to say that we should close down the industry and put a number of Australians out of work, and end forever the opportunity to realise the true potential of this native resource.

Finally, I want to refer to the last point which concerns value-adding. The Democrats have prescribed in the motion that there should be some downstream processing but only in the ways that they say. As a member of this Government, I must say that I cannot anticipate the mind of future science. I do not know what the perfect ways of developing a resource might be and I am not proposing to tie myself down to a prescription which is articulated in a motion which says, `It can only be this way because we can imagine no other'. I have learnt that more innovative, imaginative and scientifically sound ways may be found in the future. Paragraph (c) in the motion is too prescriptive; it is meant to choke off or to stifle any possibility for development. While some of the elements of the motion are idealistic and relate to things about which we would like to see more done, this may not of itself be the only way.

In the half minute left to me, let me say in summary: there is no choice for Australians concerned about balancing industry and environment in this country. Only one party-the Hawke Labor Party-is showing a clear interest in that subject. The Opposition does not and that is fundamental. I say to the Democrats: please push us harder; please carry the debate more strongly on scientific merits, on matters of fact, because we are dedicated to getting the combinations right. But do not expect us to respond when they come up with airy-fairy, wide ranging, idealistic options that are not realistic in practice and which will destroy the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this quite extraordinary motion. I realise that, as a Tasmanian born and raised in the bush, I may have advantages over some other senators. I have strong feelings for the bush and for the people who are still associated with it. I am not one of those who see it as just something else to convert or to shut up and close down. I see it very much as one of those vibrant and living things that we have a lot to be thankful for.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember very well my young days on a farm when removing the remains of trees was, from time to time, a very major undertaking. I still look on those days with some fondness, difficult and all as they may have been. I have seen trees from that area cut into scantling and into finishing timbers; I have seen it go into veneer boards, firewood and wood pulp; and recently I have seen it go into chips. I have seen that land running sheep and cattle and growing crops of potatoes, oats, swedes, peas and various other things. More recently I have seen the wheel turn full circle and much of that land has now been planted with trees, both radiata pine and eucalypts.

As a child, I knew our area very well. I knew every type of animal and bird in it and I knew every type of vegetation that grew upon it. I saw the trees grow and I saw them die. I saw the fires and I saw the regrowth. Of course, that is all very much part of the continuing cycle of the forest, and every part of it is important. I am not one, I believe, who is out of touch with the trees and the forests. So today we find ourselves with the Australian Democrats' motion, which reads:
The need to establish a pattern of ecologically sustainable development of the forest products industry requiring the Federal Government to:
(a) ensure that nearly all of Australia's sawn timber requirements are met from plantations by the year 2000;
(b) phase out export wood chipping of native forests by 1995, and;
(c) increase value-adding in the pulp and paper industry through an import replacement strategy based on moderate scale, chlorine-free pulp mills fed from hardwood plantations and recycled paper.

I am not sure what it means. I was wondering, when I first read it, whether it was the first flicker of light at the end of the tunnel. I wondered whether the Democrats had come to realise that some form of industry, even in some way, was essential; that we have to have something to live on. If that were the case, I thought we ought to take it reasonably seriously. It is a concession I gather that they do understand that we must have and use trees, that we must make pulp and paper and that we must survive in the real world.

It says, `The need to establish' but it does not say by whom. Is it the Democrats, the Senate or the Parliament? I cannot really imagine but, according to the motion, there is a need for somebody to do the establishing.

Then the motion refers to the question of sustainability. There never has been any doubt that this party has always seen sustainable development as an absolute national essential, and the position still stands. We must sustain Australia as a viable operation. The forest products industry must play its part. The forest products must be maintained and developed, and they must be developed in perpetuity as they are currently. We hope, of course, that that will be done in a continuing and increasing way.

In the State of Tasmania, with all its forest land, there are large areas of degenerate mixed forests that have little or no beauty, are of no use, are poor habitat and are not unique. Large areas of them have been badly damaged by age, fires and predators. A lot of them are badly needing renovation and restoration. A lot of these areas must be recycled so that the best of them can be regained for the future.
The motion goes on:
. . . ensure that nearly all of Australia's sawn timber-

How much is `nearly all'? Is it 51 per cent, 75 per cent or 95 per cent? Who is going to determine it? What are we going to do with it? Does the use of that timber matter? Whatever it is, it has to be `met from plantations by the year 2000'. Well, really! I have seen a lot of the trees that we are talking about-these Tasmanian blue gums and nitans that are the main varieties of the area-and I have seen them growing at extraordinary rates, but they will not grow at a rate that is quite as extraordinary as expected by the motion, I can promise honourable senators. So I ask: is the motion serious to put the year 2000 on it? It really makes the whole thing incredible.

Private forestry, particularly that coming from the forestry companies, is heading well on the way to becoming self-sufficient, as it has been for some years. In my own area, Associated Pulp and Paper Mills, the division of North Broken Hill, has done a lot of work in reforestation, and has developed many new techniques. It has one of the best plantation seedling areas that I could ever imagine and, with the use of all types of methods, it has produced exceptionally fine trees. It has already planted 18,000 hectares of eucalypts and 12,000 hectares of pines. It is increasing its plantings year by year, but those trees will not be ready by the year 2000, and certainly there is no way they can be ready by the year 2000 to meet the sawn timber requirements. I think any sort of discussion on the subject would clearly demonstrate to anybody who is interested in our becoming self-sufficient that it will take longer than that.

Also, we also have the woodlot farmers, those growing areas of upgraded native forest, putting in plantation areas and so on. We need to look after those people because we are going to rely on them. I gather from the motion that the Democrats would like to see something happen there as well. But their own policies make this extraordinarily difficult because, when I look at their policies for those sorts of people trying to make a living on the land, I find the Democrats would introduce death duties for properties worth more than $300,000; they would introduce federal land tax; they would continue to strengthen the capital gains tax; they would place stricter bureaucratic controls over all areas of agriculture, including land use; and they would repeal the planned variety rights legislation and so on. What sort of encouragement is that for people who would like to see an expansion of their development of farming in this form?

We must produce our own because we are getting further and further into debt. I found that in 1974-75, after 75 years of federation, we had a gross overseas debt of $6 billion. By 1988-89-15 years later-the debt was $139 billion. We cannot go on heading in that direction. Whatever the Labor Party in government may do or may have done, I think the people of Australia now realise that that trend must stop, and it can only stop by our producing more and selling more.

We have various problems in Australia and it was only recently, when I was trying to explain to people how it was becoming difficult, that I realised that the average Australian business in employing labour is up for these sorts of costs and conditions: a 35-hour week, 17 1/2 per cent leave loading, 10 public holidays, things they call `RDOs', four to six weeks holiday, 13 weeks long service leave, flextime, sick pay, redundancy payments, maternity leave, training levies, workers compensation, smokos, superannuation, paternity leave, specially listed clothing in many industries, transport, danger money, height money, cold money, hot money and all the other sorts of moneys that Senator Cook was able to organise in his years in the business, equal pay, equal opportunity, junior pay levels-all these sorts of things; and that is before one comes around to company tax, payroll tax, fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, payroll tax on fringe benefits tax, fuel taxes, land taxes, municipal rates and so on.

Why do people face trying to go into business when they have these types of imposts compared to their competition around the world? Our working conditions in industry are the envy of everybody in the world, and all these benefits, conditions and awards were produced while Australia was one of the most profitable and prosperous countries ever. We no longer can say that; it is not so by a mile. We have to keep on going and we have to get back on track. We cannot get out of export woodchipping by 1995. What would we do with the heads, the rubbish and the off-cuts and so on? What would we do with our contracts, our debts and our unemployment? Do the Australian Democrats give a continental about these things? Do they, or do they not? We have to make these targets reasonable, attainable and sensible.

Finally, we come to the import replacement question, and that has to be reasonable, too. To say what sort and size of plant we are talking about is quite ridiculous. The chlorine plant is the current state of the art in the world. It may change, but the new plant is as good as anything we could wish for. Why do we want to produce a moderate size-by which I presume they mean an uneconomic size-plant? Then there is recycled paper: the paper processors in Australia tell me they are already using the maximum amount of recyclable paper they can without lowering their standards below what the market requires. We cannot produce paper that is not required; we must look to the future to be able to see that we supply what the world wants, not what the Democrats want. It must be what the market requires.
I will give notice of an amendment to be moved later, which says:
Remove all words after `urgency', substitute:

The need to establish a pattern of sustainable development of the $8 billion a year forest products industry in order to lessen Australia's annual $2 billion dependence on imports and increase the value of its exports, requiring the federal government to:

(a) encourage the industry to meet the bulk of its sawn timber requirements from plantations and those areas of native forests that are not reserved for the maintenance of necessary environmental and bio-diversity requirements; and

(b) provide a base of confidence and security to enable the pulp and paper industry substantially to increase value adding through a strategy of development of pulp and paper mills meeting agreed national standards in line with the best available technology so that Australian wood resources have as much `added value' as possible in Australia rather than overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many matters need to be addressed and cleared up before I proceed on the substance of what I want to say. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook was under the misapprehension-and I direct him to the Hansard record-that we were talking about a matter of public importance. I have only just learnt about these things; I expected Senator Cook to have it straight by now. In fact, the letter from Senator Coulter clearly says that today he `shall move the following as a matter of urgency'. For Senator Cook to address it as a matter of public importance is quite misleading.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't change a single remark I made, however.

—If it does not, it probably means that Senator Cook has a little packet of words which he carts about and throws around whenever something like this comes up; that in fact it was not a speech addressed to this matter, but rather a speech he trots out on provocation. Senator Cook's speech was based upon the idea that we needed to have some facts before us before we could address this particular problem.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as I understand it, in addressing Senator Coulter's urgency motion we need a set of principles. It is those principles which really determine how we react to this motion. Senator Cook did not address those principles, but seemed to think it was important to spend some time dismissing the speculation in the press. While he was addressing and dismissing that speculation and trying to hose down the concern of some members of the Cabinet about it, we did not hear what I would have expected to hear from a Labor senator. We did not hear concern about the principles of what is our Crown land, who owns our forests, how should we use them, who should use them, who should be entitled to exploit them and whether any exploitation should be allowed whatsoever. They are the principles, concerns and policy directions with which we are concerned and it matters very little about anything other than the title of the proposed legislation, about which we have heard so much in the past few weeks; that is, the legislation about which we Democrats have been asking a series of questions and have been receiving very little satisfaction on: the legislation referred to as resource security legislation.

Senator Cook also mentioned his idea that the Australian Democrats can afford to be critical because we have no responsibility and will not have the responsibility of reaching government in his foreseeable future. In case Senator Cook has not noticed, the Democrats occupy a position in this place at the moment which gives us what is referred to as the `balance of power'; it is a position which requires the daily exercise of a responsible attitude to all legislation. That means that every day and on every issue nothing that this Government proposes can be passed in this place without critical and responsible evaluation by either the coalition or the Democrats, and sometimes the coalition has lately reduced our impact by forming its own greater coalition with the Government. That greater coalition has taken us down the path of abandoning many of the very Labor principles with which this Government should be concerned. I suggest that Senator Cook realises that responsibility is not necessarily only responsibility in government; it also applies to responsibility in consideration of all legislation.

We were told some of the facts, with which we have no dispute: approximately 10 per cent of our current account deficit is due to timber imports. This is a matter which has concerned me personally for some time. Some 30 years ago, in the area in which I lived when I was much younger, I was fortunate enough to be aware of what was going on in my environment. As children quite often we do not take much notice of our environment, but I listened and observed. I lived in an area which was used for some of the earliest pine plantations established in Tasmania. I was aware at the time and took notice of the fact that when the early plantations were established some of the timbers which were trialled, some of the plants which were established as trials, were not just pinus radiata, but pinus insignia and what we also call Douglas Fir or oregon. I think we still import oregon to a great extent from North America. Oregon grows very well in conditions similar to those required for radiata, which covers extensive areas of softwood plantations in Australia. Although I was aware that some plantings took place earlier on, I still cannot understand why more extensive plantings of Douglas Fir were not made. Perhaps the investors at that time could not see the need to make plans over such long periods which the Douglas Fir requires to grow.

During his information sharing session, Senator Cook told us what would happen to imports if we reduced our dependence on Australian native timbers. I was a bit troubled, as was Senator Archer by his reference to the word `we'. Senator Cook also used the word `you', and I do not understand whom he meant. He said, `You push responsibility on to Penan, Sarawak, et cetera, to provide us with the sorts of timbers that we need to supply our building needs'. I do know a little about this. In the past, before I was enlightened, I used some of the timbers which are supplied as Asian rainforest species. I realised that the timbers, such as Meranti and Merbau, are often supplied as architraves or as skirting boards, et cetera. We do not need to use that type of timber for that particular application. There are many others, and certainly the softwood plantations could and should provide the timber which is used in that way. It is certainly not used in an exotic manner which requires it to be that particular timber; if anything, it is almost a substitute for it. We do not require the rainforest species of South East Asia to be used in that way. The simple fact is that we should not import it at all. We can and should use radiata for that purpose.

We are told, again in an information sharing exercise by Senator Cook, that 15 years is required to grow eucalypts for pulp. That is precisely the reason Senator Coulter's motion reads that `nearly all' Australia's timber will provide for that. People have a certain blindness when asked: what should we do? Should we replace all that we are importing or all that we are cutting down tomorrow with something which does not exist? It does not exist simply because there has not been enough foresight, planning or forward notions in industrial circles by the very people who wish to exploit our native resources.

Yesterday I spent most of the day in areas with which Senator Archer would be familiar-Scottsdale, Branxholme, Weldborough and Myrtle Park. I spent a considerable time at Myrtle Park. I lived there some 30 years ago. Yesterday I noticed the changes in those areas as being considerable. Much of the native forest has been replaced with plantations. But only recently has there been any effort whatsoever to establish the eucalypt plantations mentioned by Senator Cook. On the ground, where timber is produced in Tasmania, we can see very little evidence of eucalypt plantation. There is not enough planning and not enough investment in the establishment of the industry's own resources. Senator Cook asked which entrepreneurs would invest billions of dollars in pulp mill projects without the security that the resource will be available in the future. That is the crux of this whole matter; that is the essence of it. That was the threat-legislation or we do not establish our industry. That is what it is all about. I ask: which entrepreneurs are prepared to back up a plan to establish industry with investment based not on the exploitation of our resources, but rather on the establishment of their own resources, on their land bought and paid for using their trees and established and nurtured with their money through their own efforts? We will then see who is serious about establishing industry. Anything short of that is exploitation of our resources; anything short of that should be condemned for what it is-greed.

In 1984 I spent three months in New Zealand. I visited an 1890 prison farm which had been established to accommodate those who were incarcerated at Her Majesty's pleasure. The work that was to be undertaken by those unfortunate souls was planting trees. Some 94 years later I visited the area and I was surprised and pleased to find a tree that I could not identify. It was a specimen remnant left after the initial clearing, which was done in the 1940s, and the last clearing, which was done in the 1960s. A specimen or two were left, and they were Tasmanian blackwoods. Some 90 years earlier New Zealand had shown the foresight to establish a plantation of timber which we considered to be far too slow growing to provide a predictable income.

The other evidence of foresight in that area was the existence of Californian redwoods. They were approaching their 100th year and still had 50 or 60 years to go before they provided the fruits of investment which that country had placed in them. I see that as being foresight and planning; I see that as the sort of thing upon which we should base industry proposals. Until that occurs we will not see a real commitment from those individuals or corporations which really have the benefit of the country at heart rather than their own personal wealth.

We understand that a motion will be moved which alters the urgency motion. I suggest that the motion I have received consists of complicated words which hide the principle that full and complete exploitation of our forests is the right of industrial developers. Senator Archer has indicated that Senator Coulter's urgency motion may be subject to alteration. It certainly goes a long way towards achieving the establishment of the sorts of principles which I would have thought this Labor Government would have endorsed and should endorse in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is little doubt that the motion before the Senate today from Senator Coulter is motivated by the current debate on resource security legislation. In my contribution to this debate, I intend to deal with four broad areas. The first will be an overview of our Government's approach on this question of resource security; the second will be an examination of the Tasmanian approach through the Tasmanian forest industry strategy, which to a significant extent has contributed or led to this process of resource security legislation; the third area will be an examination of the motion presented to this Senate by Senator Coulter; and, fourthly, I want to highlight the disjointed approach of those opposite in their contribution to this issue generally, not just in this debate today but in the community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: As desirable as it may appear to some for society and governments to embrace a nature conservation ethic, there is a danger of over-reaction, of moving beyond that equilibrium where adequate account is taken of the wider public interest. The critical threshold question to be addressed by governments is what is a fair and reasonable balance between wood production and forest conservation. Until comparatively recently, governments had not established an adequate planning framework within which that question could be addressed and appropriate forest strategies developed. A new sectoral approach to forest policy is required if we are adequately to identify and protect the environmental and heritage values of our native forests and concurrently-I emphasise the word `concurrently'-meet the objectives of economic and social policy.

Commentators have invariably focused on the issue of resource security. It should be emphasised that resource security is only one part of a comprehensive, transparent and integrated approach to these issues. In spite of attempts to introduce the concept of a forest conservation and development process into the forest debate, most of the discussion is still a potent mixture of assertion, distorted claims and doomsday prophecies, such as we have seen over the last two or three days. Much of this has centred upon the little understood term `resource security', which is a fine example of just how dangerous words can be in the political debate.

To illustrate this point, many commentators have pre-emptively condemned resource security, without having had the benefit of understanding what it means, where it fits or where it comes from. They have replaced fact with assertion. The essential point that should be strongly put is that resource security is not about providing uncontrolled access to Australia's valuable forests-as the Australian Democrats would assert, for example-but about providing access for use by the forest products industry. Nor does it involve governments, particularly the Federal Government, abrogating its commitment to protect Australia's precious forest environment and heritage values. Indeed, the contrary is the case. Resource security is the final stage in a comprehensive process to identify and protect the environmental and heritage values of our forests and, importantly, to enhance employment-which is a big issue in the community at the present time and particularly an issue in the State I represent-through encouraging a secure and thriving forest products industry.

The process represents a new approach by the Commonwealth and State governments to better coordinate and integrate existing government policies. It is worth noting that the Commonwealth Government accepts the need to provide resource security. The issue to be resolved is whether the level of security should be based on legislation or remain at the current level of security, or lack of it, as provided for under existing non-statutory Commonwealth-State forestry agreements.

With that background, I am concerned to explain the quality of the environmental and heritage assessment process which will precede any secure access arrangements. Only when we can be assured that environmental and heritage values have been identified and adequately protected can we be confident in providing State governments and the industry with an appropriate and assured level of access to multiple use forests, the lifeblood of our renewable timber and paper products industry.

Having said that, I should point out that the forest conservation and development process consists of five sequential stages, each dependent upon the satisfactory completion of the previous stage, which are as follows: stage 1, the formulation of a forestry conservation and development strategy by State governments and the forestry industry; stage 2, the integrated Commonwealth-State assessment of environmental, heritage, economic and social issues; stage 3, Commonwealth-State agreements which are to be ratified by respective governments; stage 4, Commonwealth legislation, if accepted by Cabinet, to clearly define areas of forest available for multiple uses, including wood production; and stage 5, implementation of the resource security process.

Taken together, rather than weakening the Government's environment and heritage legislation, the elements of the process leading to legislative support for value adding investments would strengthen the integration of environmental and economic considerations by ensuring that all relevant aspects are addressed in advance of government decisions on forest use. The Australian community will realise only the benefits from properly managed and conserved forests if a secure Commonwealth and State forest conservation and development process is in place which encompasses an appropriate level of resource security.

In the 1989-90 years Australia's trade deficit in forest products accounted for 10 per cent of our total account deficit. Australia now relies significantly on imports of forest products, and the value of forest product imports has increased by over 120 per cent since 1983-84. The industry is also Australia's second largest manufacturing industry, employing around 250,000 people in the forest, forest products, printing and allied industries.

If an appropriate policy framework for resource security is not provided, Australian forest product companies will continue to invest offshore. Some of Australia's largest forest product companies now derive a significant proportion of their revenue from recent offshore investment in the pulp and paper sector. Recently I visited Indonesia and, in conversation with various industry officials, including those of Austrade, it was made very clear to me that that process of investment offshore from Australia will continue and increase very rapidly unless in this country we get this debate right. This pattern can be expected to continue unless governments in Australia can restore confidence in this sector.

Recent advice from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and the Bureau of Industry Economics suggests that the macro-economic effects of increased investment in the hardwood industry are very substantial. The long term macro-economic effects of an assumed increase in investment and production in the hardwood processing sector have been analysed by the Industry Commission's Oriana model. The simulation was based on a $4.1 billion investment in the pulp and paper sector. The effects were found to be as follows: an increase in real gross domestic product of 0.4 per cent, approximately $1.5 billion per year; an increase in real wages of 0.6 per cent; and an improvement in the trade account.

Importantly, the advice also considered the effects to the year 2000 of a cessation of investment in additional capacity in hardwood processing. Frankly, that is really what the Democrats are all about-a cessation of investment in this industry to bring about its very substantial reduction in this country. The sobering effect of a cessation was found to be an increase in the value of imports, in 1988 and 1989-90 prices, of forest products, exclusive of such paper manufactures as boxes and bags, from $1.8 billion to $2.5 billion in the year 2000-an increase of 39 per cent. In addition, assuming that there is no change in the value of exports of forest products from the 1989-90 level of $0.5 billion, the value of net forest product imports is expected to increase from $1.3 billion to $2 billion in the year 2000-an increase of 54 per cent.

Those sorts of figures this nation can ill afford, given the current problems we face with our balance of payments. These statistics have an important message for this Government and for this country. There can be no doubt that the concessions for a higher level of security of resource access have had an impact on investment in the forest sectors. Security of access is, of course, only one of a number of factors that determine whether investment in modernisation, restructuring or value adding occurs. Notwithstanding the other commercial aspects of an investment proposal, unless there is certainty of resource there will be no investment in projects of any significance and particularly-and this is the next area I wish to come to-in my home State of Tasmania.

In Tasmania the State Labor Government, led by Premier Michael Field, embarked on a strategy some two years ago of drawing together the various parties in the forest industry and over a period of 18 months it has produced a report known as the forest industry strategy. That strategy is a total document in terms of the problems it addresses in the forest industry. It does not just examine the problems of pulpwood and paper production; it does not just examine the issues of conservation. It has a totally integrated approach to such matters as veneer products, forest operations and the practices code, pulpwood, forest resources, conservation, wood supply agreements and the end of the concession system.

This point has been missed in the entire debate on resource security legislation. In Tasmania the companies, as part of this strategy, have agreed to the end of the concession system, a system under which previous governments gave enormous slabs of the forest in Tasmania to companies which, until quite recently, virtually had carte blanche in terms of the way in which they exploited those forestry concessions. The companies have agreed that this system should end but they want a firm commitment on wood supply to enable them to invest. Last but not least, there are the important people's issues such as health and safety and other industrial issues that affect people who work in the industry, and such problems are all too often forgotten.

The matter of urgency moved by the Australian Democrats is in three parts. The first part, as Senator Cook said, is an idealistic approach and may well be something that we can work towards. But in terms of the practical parameters of what is achievable in the forest industry, paragraph (a) is frankly nonsense. That paragraph says that by the year 2000 nearly all of Australia's sawn timber requirements should be met from plantations. That is simply not attainable because factually and biologically it is an impossibility. We in Tasmania cannot possibly convert our sawn timber industry to a plantation based industry in the next 10 years. The forest simply will not grow fast enough. The reality of paragraph (a) is that it would bring the Tasmanian forest industry to a substantial grinding halt. There would be a reduction of some 50 per cent of output. Therefore, the proposal is simply not achievable.

Paragraph (b) relates to the phasing out of export woodchipping of native forests by 1995. I say yes to that, and the sooner it happens the better. The only way that will happen is if we start to build some of the pulp mills that have been held back in recent years. The only way to ensure the end of the woodchipping industry in this country is to ensure that the pulp and paper mills are built. As for the time scale of 1995, if we could sit down tomorrow and reach agreement on this issue, it would still be at least another 10 years before there is a substantial reduction in our export of woodchips.
Finally, paragraph (c) requires the Government to:
. . . increase value-adding in the pulp and paper industry through an import replacement strategy based on moderate scale, chlorine-free pulp mills . . .

The only problem with that part of the matter of urgency is that no-one wants to build moderate scale, chlorine-free pulp mills at present. In Tasmania the only proposal before the State Government is for a world scale-a large scale-integrated mill using a chlorine base for the operation of the mill. When one looks at the scientific studies-and there have been a significant number of such studies into this issue-I very much regret that we have to continue to use a chlorine base, but it is the only feasible, practical option that appears to be able to be used in this country for the next five to 10 years. Again, by proposing to adopt paragraph (c), in effect the Democrats are saying no to any new development in this area at all.

I close by saying that the Liberal Party's approach is little better. The Liberals do not have a policy in Tasmania. The former Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in Tasmania, Mr Groom, accepted this forest industry strategy. But when Mr Gray, who is notorious for his attitude to environmental questions, decided that that was not an appropriate way, Mr Groom resigned in disgust.

in another four years. They say that all woodchipping of native forests should be abandoned. Where do we get the resources from for the pulp mill we are to put up-solely from plantations?
