SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tragedy of this debate today is that, if the arguments put forward by the conservation movement had been heeded 15 or so years ago when there was first the promotion of the plantation option, the timber from plantations would now be available to come on line and we would probably not have needed this urgency motion today, which I wholeheartedly support. Two overriding points need to be made clear. The first deals with the myth of jobs versus the environment and the kind of argument put forward by people like Senator Walsh-that greenies are against jobs. The second concerns the fate of our old growth forests which can never be replaced.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been an overall decline in the number of jobs in the forest industry over the last two decades, a decline which has nothing to do with the greenies. This decline continues despite Senator Walsh's allegation that conservationists are middle-class trendoids living in the eastern suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne and that they do not care about blue-collar workers with limited skills and education, living in areas of high unemployment. Many of these blue-collar workers will lose their jobs in the next 20 years and would lose their jobs even if the eastern suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne were to vanish this afternoon-blasted out of existence by Senator Walsh's venom. The unemployment Senator Walsh refers to has been caused largely by automation, by changing market forces in the harsh export climate; not the big city suburban trendoids with which he has such an obsession.

Senator Cook, in his speech this afternoon, also resorted to abuse by saying that Senator Coulter was ignoring serious analysis while he, of course, was calling for a dispassionate objective critique of the issue-a classic tactic when one has no substance on which to build one's own argument.

Before continuing, I think it is also worth referring to the ongoing campaign to save the south-eastern forests, some three hours drive from Canberra. The Canberra Times on Saturday had an excellent article on the fight for the forests by Maria Taylor outlining the economic factors that are changing the face of the forest industry, whatever measures the Government might introduce tomorrow evening. The writer also dealt with the highly critical report of the New South Wales Forestry Commission which, according to the Liberal State member for Mosman, Phillip Smiles, is one of the most damning reports the New South Wales Public Accounts Committee has brought down.

Looking ahead, the fact is that the majority of the Australian hardwood sawmillers are unlikely to survive the competition now emerging from New Zealand, South Africa, Brazil, Portugal and Spain, and the forest industry knows this, which is why it is making a strong bid to utilise the narrow window of opportunity available to it in the short term and why it has got to rip the guts out of the native forests before that is not a viable option for it.

The outcome of the rapidly increasing supply of softwoods from domestic and imported plantation sources will lead to a substantial decline in native forest sawlogging over the next 10 years on purely commercial grounds, which will have nothing to do with the push by environmentalists to preserve the old-growth forests. The National Association of Forest Industries claims that, without resource security legislation, up to $4.99 billion worth of investment in the industry will be forgone, yet Dr Robert Bain, the Director of NAFI, has clearly indicated that the passage of resource legislation would not guarantee that investment would proceed. In other words, as Mr Keating would describe it, we have the legislation that we do not need.

As the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) has argued, the current push for resource security is, above all else, aimed at securing large volumes of woodchips from native forests for the manufacture of paper pulp. This argument was backed up by Maria Taylor in her article in the Canberra Times on Saturday. She made the point that the resource security debate to date has been unclear, because politicians and some industry lobbyists have downplayed woodchip and pulp exports and couched the appeal for resource security in terms of jobs for Australian workers and survival for small town sawmills. Her article states:

In fact, most of the profit now is in woodchipping. Japanese chip exporter Harris Daishowa has enjoyed extraordinary profits exceeding 20 per cent on annual sales in recent years. Analyses submitted to the Resource Assessment Commission variously translated this into after-tax shareholders' dividends of between 60-100 per cent since 1987.

The full page advertisements placed by NAFI in the major daily newspapers last week are a good example of the industry's approach, with the list of small towns whose future is allegedly at stake without resource guarantee legislation wanted by the industry. But, of course, the industry is not making any reciprocal guarantees to the Government, and the Government may end up having to pay compensation to the industry at a later date.

The reality is that the conservation movement is, and always has been, concerned about employment. In submissions made to the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry environmental groups have argued that, in the long term, jobs can best be guaranteed through the establishment of plantation grown hardwoods, not through the logging of our irreplaceable old-growth native forests. Once the old-growth native forests have gone, they have gone for ever. With them go countless numbers of species of the animal, bird and insect world.

It is also relevant at this point to draw the Senate's attention to an article in today's West Australian by a leading Perth scientist, Jennifer McComb of Murdoch University's school of biological and environmental sciences. She made the point at a biotechnology conference that Australia's genetic heritage in native trees could be exploited for sale to countries fighting severe land degradation problems. Here is another potential loss if we continue to log our old-growth forests at will.

A Saulwick poll last year indicated that 78 per cent of people asked agreed that native forests were a valuable part of our environment and should be preserved wherever possible. The ACF has pointed out that all of Australia's pulpwood supply could be met from plantations within 15 years, and most sawlog needs within 30 years. That is why Senator Coulter carefully worded his motion to say that nearly all of Australia's sawn timber requirements can be met from plantations by the year 2000.

Why, then, is there this push from industry to guarantee it access to the old-growth forests? Export woodchipping is highly profitable at the moment although the situation will change within a decade, as I have already indicated. The pulp and paper industry knows that it will have to rely much more on plantation supplied resources but, in the meantime, it wants ready access to an underpriced, largely publicly subsidised, resource-our native forests. This is a classic example of why the conservation movement insists on ecologically sustainable development, looking ahead to the future, rather than going for quick profits with no long term employment prospects for workers in the industry and the decimation of what remains of our old-growth forests.

Those members of parliament who have bothered to read the ACF briefing paper on resource security prepared for them this month will know that the issue we are really addressing in the third part of Senator Coulter's motion is whether or not the shift to domestic value adding in the pulp and paper industry is accompanied by a transition to plantation based supply. Environmentalists know that it is no good being against something even if you are not in favour of a constructive alternative. Mahatma Gandhi, who has inspired so many of us in our non-violent resistance to save native forests, repeatedly stressed this point.

Our critics constantly misrepresent us, as Senator Walsh did last week in Adelaide, by making the inaccurate allegation that, every time the ACF has a political victory, more Australians lose their jobs. What absolute twaddle! Conservationists have argued time and time again for a transition strategy for the forest products industry which implements a move to a plantation based import replacement industry.

As the ACF briefing document put it, such an industry should rely on moderate scale pulp mills using a variety of feedstocks and extensive recycling. Where bleaching is necessary, this should be chlorine free. Discharge of organochlorin effluents into the environment should not be permitted. This is an ecologically sustainable alternative which would put the industry on a secure, long term footing and ensure protection of Australia's remaining unique native forests.

I would now like to turn my attention to my home State of Western Australia. This debate has particular relevance to the Western Australian forest industry where a timber strategy is in place that sets aside only 30 per cent of native forests for conservation, and guarantees the timber industry access to 70 per cent of that resource. This is hardly a balanced or sustainable approach.

With regard to the first part of Senator Coulter's proposal that most of Australia's sawn timber be met from plantations by the year 2000, Western Australia has already established pine plantations on State owned land and has introduced a pine share farming program whereby it has established a lease agreement with farmers to grow pines. However, the Government, under former Premier Dowding, made a commitment to establish a tree trust to encourage direct incentives to farmers and members of the public to develop major plantations, and the promised incentives have not been fulfilled. The State Government needs to diversify from its existing pine plantations into hardwood, which was a major thrust of the tree trust which has not reached fruition.

As for the phasing out of woodchipping in native forests, this has particular relevance to the jarrah and karri forests of the south west which are under threat from the forest industry and where questions have been raised, as in New South Wales, about the lack of efficiency in the industry. We urgently need to reduce the volume of forests clear felled through smaller, more efficient timber mills with better recovery rates.

As for pulp mills, much of the focus will be on Tasmania but the Western Australian State Government also has a proposal for a pulp mill near Bunbury which would process 1.3 million tonnes of pulp, a far greater volume than could now be sustained locally from plantations. Where they would get their resources from is a big question mark at the moment.

There are also siting problems with this proposal because of the scarcity of a fresh water resource in the south west and the need for large volumes of water for the processing. The organosolv process of pulp production seems to be the cleanest process in the near future. In this process timber is treated with a mix of water and alcohols to produce bleached pulp.

There is a group based in the Netherlands which has the cleanest process, but it is still a couple of years from commercial production. Another reason why some of the big companies want to get in, in the very short term, is that they realise that there is environmentally sound technology very near to fruition in other countries. In Germany there is a mill, but it will not be in full production until 1992. The mills in the Netherlands and Germany have the advantage of being able to use a wide variety of fibres-softwood, hardwood and plant fibres.

Overall, the Western Australian Government must see that there is great potential for regrowth of monocultures other than just pine to support a plantation pulp system. Blue gum monocultures are now being introduced, but the Government must integrate its proposals as part of a holistic farm planning strategy so that plantations can be placed on cleared farmlands and salt affected areas near water courses so that they benefit the environment in a holistic way.

It is interesting to note that in this debate both the Labor and Liberal speakers have chosen to stray away from the motion and to abuse each other because, essentially, they agree with each other. The real difference in Australian politics is now between the Laborials on one side and the Greens and Democrats on the other. This motion is an excellent example of what I am talking about. It reminds me of the eighteenth century English diarist, Hazlitt, who compared the Whigs and Tories to a couple of passenger coaches going down the same highway, splashing each other with mud but both going to the same place.

Senator Sherry rightly pointed to the resource security issue as the trigger for this debate, although I am sorry that he once again repeated the hoary old chestnut that environmentalists are against job creation, which is a nonsense. Environmentalists are very concerned about job creation, and make that a basic platform for all of their arguments.

Why, then, has the Government chosen to make the decision it will announce tomorrow night? We have not been privileged to hear the details of this decision, we only have the broad framework of it at the moment. This is because the Government is in a panic. There is a huge split in the Cabinet that has been well documented. The thin veneer of luke-green scratches off very easily post election, despite Senator Cook's claim to represent a green movement, which I find highly offensive.

This Government is in a mad scramble to give a signal, no matter how high the price, to show industry that Labor really cares about jobs. If only that were the case. The public sector job cuts in rural areas do far more damage to country areas than the decline of the forest industry. Yet Labor stands by an industry which has neglected its own responsibilities to plant its own timbers. I wish to address the Commonwealth Grants Commission Report on the Interstate Distribution of General Purpose Grants for Local Government 1991. One of the problems concerning this document is that it is so large and so extensive that it is impossible for one to digest it in the short time available. Senator Short alluded to this earlier and also to the five minutes which has been allocated to speeches in this debate.

I believe after a cursory glance that the report is absolutely guaranteed to throw the cat among the pigeons. It examines the two basic methods of funding local government in the specific grants area. The two methods of issuing grants to local government through the States grants commissions is the per capita allocation, which is the existing situation, and fiscal equalisation, the alternative. It appears from the report that the Commonwealth Grants Commission comes down strongly on the side of fiscal equalisation. It is worth quoting some aspects of the report. It states:
The Commonwealth Treasury and the Commonwealth Office of Local Government agreed that, in principle, fiscal equalisation should be used, but that cost effectiveness should also be considered.
The report also makes the point:
. . . only Victoria questioned the appropriateness of fiscal equalisation as the basis of future distribution of local government assistance.

This appeared to be somewhat of a shock to the State grants commissions because, in another part, the report says, in effect, that if under investigation it was found that fiscal equalisation approximated per capita grants it would be better to stay with per capita grants for simplicity. No-one will disagree with that, but the investigation showed that the fiscal equalisation approach was quite different in its outcome from making per capita grants.

The two methods used by the Commission to look at general purpose assistance showed that under the institutional per capita relativities and implied interstate distribution-one method which, I might say, the Commission rejected, or at least did not recommend-the existing allocation to Victoria, for instance, of $182.4m would drop to $40.2m; the existing allocation to New South Wales of $243.1m would drop to $74m; and for Queensland the allocation would increase from $120.4m to $293m.

Under table 2 on page xviii, the complementary per capita relativities and implied State distribution show that the following changes would occur. For Victoria, the existing allocation of $182.4m would drop to $90.3m, and for New South Wales the present allocation of $243.1m would drop to $81.9m. For Queensland the existing allocation of $120m would increase to $260.4m, and for Tasmania the allocation of $19m would increase to $37.4m. It is quite obvious that under fiscal equalisation, even though that method was supported by the Treasury and the department responsible for local government, the bigger States would lose out and the smaller States would gain. I could not help but notice that a lot of mathematical formulae were used which are totally unintelligible to the layman. It reminded me that Einstein on his theory of relativity said that, when the mathematicians came to prove them, he could not understand his own calculations. It is somewhat disappointing after 12 months that another study is suggested. This is a major report which is impossible to digest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission is a very complicated document-as Senator Parer has pointed out. It comes about as a result of a request on 22 March 1990 from the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Stewart West, when he wrote to the Chairman of the Commonwealth Grants Commission stating, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the terms of reference for a review by the Commonwealth Grants Commission of inter-State distribution of local government general purpose grants.

The Commission was asked to reply to the Government by 28 February 1991. It has done that, and I compliment the Commission on its promptness. As Senator Parer said, it has given us a 254-page, very complicated document.

As is pointed out in the overview of the report, the then Minister's letter specified six separate requirements for that inquiry. Senator Parer has already mentioned requirements one and two. I wish to comment on requirement five. The Grants Commission was asked to make an analysis of whether the application of the principle of fiscal equalisation is appropriate to determine the distribution of general purpose assistance for local government among the States in the future. In response, the Commission said:
We believe it is feasible to determine per capita relativities suitable for distributing general purpose assistance for local government . . . on an equalisation basis.

To a lot of local government areas, that is very good news. The Commission did say, however, that whether it is appropriate or not to adopt relativities based on fiscal equalisation is something that has to be looked at because it is not a simple question. The Commission stated:

In principle, we believe it would not be appropriate to continue indefinitely an interstate distribution of general purpose assistance for local government on a basis (equal per capita) which departs so markedly from fiscal equalisation.

Then it goes on to say that in practice there are several different ways in which it can be done. It makes the point that the per capita basis of distribution of funds is simple and predictable, and that equalisation would be much more complex. In the second part of this recommendation-and this is interesting-the Commission says:
A change to an equalisation system would entail extra administrative costs for both the Commonwealth and the States . . .
Finally, the Commission said:
A move to an equalisation basis would be very disruptive to local authorities in New South Wales and Victoria.

Of course it would be. As Senator Parer has pointed out, those States would suffer quite badly under the fiscal equalisation principles because at the present time they are being paid on a per capita basis. When I read this report-I know it is long and I have had a chance to glance only at parts of it-it is almost like the Self report of some years ago revisited. Professor Peter Self's major recommendations to the Government were that there should be some sort of fiscal equalisation for local government and that there should be factors built in that made allowances for States that were not in the position of the more populous States-those States affected by distance and all those other things that work against them. But the Government did not take that matter up and went for the per capita basis of distribution because, as it says in this report, it is simple and predictable. Now we have moved a bit further down the track and it has now asked that this inquiry be held.

In respect of future procedures, the Commission mentions that the Commonwealth Treasury and the Commonwealth Office of Local Government agree in principle to fiscal equalisation and that cost-effectiveness should be considered. As Senator Parer has pointed out, we look like having a long, protracted further inquiry into the appropriateness of fiscal equalisation. I am sure my own State of Tasmania, Western Australia and Queensland, will be looking to fiscal equalisation. Perhaps up to 10 years will be involved in looking at this. So whilst local government can take some heart from this particular paper, it will have to wait a bit longer. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

I would like to make a few remarks regarding this report. The report itself is most informative. Its format includes an introduction and pretty good explanations of the meaning of dumping and subsidisation, injurious dumping, the anti-dumping and countervailing action that might be taken, and so on. Since it does that, it should be of some assistance to the growing number of people who are concerned about the welfare of Australian industry.

The report itself takes pains to express this in language which is simple and straightforward. Some might call it plain English. I found the report most interesting and easy to read and, because it was, I managed to cover it in the few minutes made available to us to consider it before it was brought on for discussion. Page six of the report has a very good explanation of the path to be taken when somebody wants to make a claim that products had been dumped on the Australian market. It occurred to me, in following that path, that it was long and tortuous. Although it was explained well, it is a path which takes a long time to resolve.

We are told on page 6 that Customs must by law reach a prima facie decision within 55 days of the receipt of an application to consider whether dumping has taken place. If, after that prima facie decision, it finds that dumping seems to be taking place, Customs will undertake an investigation which must be concluded within 120 days. After that decision has been made the Authority allows 40 days for submissions to be made to it, and then later a report, by law, must be sent to the Minister within 120 days after the receipt of reference from Customs. During that entire process it is possible that provisional anti-dumping measures may be put in place. However, a lot of the responsibility to make representations to the Authority still lies on industry and it is the industry which would find that process long, involved and, most of all, costly.

The report refers to one of the infamous cases of a dumping claim. It was report No. 16, dated January 1990, which followed the trail of cement clinker from Saudi Arabia. On page 14 of this report the story begins in September 1988 but it is not until a report in January 1990 that there is a conclusion which, by the way, suggested that the clinker from Saudi Arabia had not caused and was not threatening any material injury to the Australian industry. It is that very material injury and the definition of the same words which create a problem for many people who wish to make a claim about dumping.

On page 3 of the introduction the report highlights the fact that these words need definition and, in fact, in appendix 1 a definition is given. I think that is one of the reasons, for example, why Senator Boswell moved to have the anti-dumping measures available referred to a committee. I hope that the committee will be able to expound upon the problems we have with dumping because many Australian industries really do not need the extra problems associated with competing with overseas industries that might have an unfair advantage over them. I hope that committee takes note of the sort of information provided by this annual report.

This is the eleventh report of the Committee concerning a matter raised by a person under Privilege Resolution 5 of 25 February 1988. On 11 December 1990, the President, Senator the Hon. The response read as follows--
RESPONSE BY SIR WILLIAM KEYS AGREED TO BY SIR WILLIAM KEYS AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5 (7) (B) OF THE SENATE OF 25 FEBRUARY 1988
In the Senate on 5 December Senator Newman further discussed matters relating to me, and I again ask that I make a response under Resolution 5.
Let me first deal with the visit to defence establishments in Northern Queensland in 1987.

For many years the RSL had complained to successive governments about Australia's weak northern defences, so when I received an invitation from Minister for Defence, Kim Beazley, to visit some of these new and improved facilities, I accepted, realising the time spent with the Minister would also give me the opportunity to canvass thoroughly matters affecting conditions of service in the case the League had put to the Government. We visited installations at and near Townsville.

Subsequently, I flew with the Minister and senior Air Force personnel to Weipa to visit the site of the new airbase. All in all, a very helpful programme which would allow the RSL to make more informed and helpful comments about Defence arrangements.

Senator Newman was in Townsville at the same time, where she was promoting the concept that funds should be transferred from the Defence re-equipment programme to Defence conditions of service. The media asked me to comment. I said that many conditions of service were in need of upgrading, expressly emphasising the need for coverage for Defence personnel under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, Turbulence Allowance, Housing and entitlements to the Defence Service Homes Scheme.

However, I went on to say that to transfer funds from equipment to personnel would not be wise, especially having regard to the long lead-time required to purchase the sophisticated and high-technology equipment we were acquiring.
I went on to say that in my view what was required was a consumption tax of one kind or another to fund an adequate Defence budget.
This proposal was quickly rejected by the Prime Minister. It is interesting to note that Senator Newman's party has now adopted a very similar proposal.
Let me now go on to Senator Newman's suggestion that I had not, over the years, effectively served well the interests of veterans and dependants in my negotiations with successive governments.

The record of my work over 45 years provides an effective response to this. Because I believe it is essential to successful representation, I made a point of developing good working relations with all Prime Ministers and Ministers for Repatriation and Veterans' Affairs.

I have received supportive testimony from Labor Prime Minister Bob Hawke and Liberal Minister for Repatriation in the Fraser Government, Tony Messner. If needed, I am certain I can obtain similar support from Prime Ministers and Ministers for Repatriation and Veterans' Affairs who were in office over the years, from both sides of Parliament. Indeed, I obtained benefits from Senator Newman's husband when he was briefly Minister for Repatriation. Also added to that can be the testimony of Sir Arthur Lee and Sir William Hall who were the National Presidents during my 17 years as National Secretary.
SIR WILLIAM KEYS

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on this new response by Sir William Keys as tabled in the report of the Committee of Privileges. That, in fact, is not correct. I believe that the Opposition's policy was misrepresented-maybe innocently; I do not know-by Sir William. He claimed that the Opposition was planning to welsh on contracts for the capital equipment program.

Sir William has not said in his response that when he was travelling in the jet of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-I am not sure whether it was the jet of the Prime Minister or the jet of the then Minister for Defence; it does not seem to matter much for the sake of my response now-travel was being undertaken during the middle of an election campaign. During my visit I visited Defence personnel and their families who were living in very poor housing and suffering very poor conditions of service, such that some of them were eligible for welfare benefits.

Sir William was travelling with the then Minister for Defence and the Prime Minister during the middle of an election campaign. Sir William Keys, the leader of one of the most conservative groups in Australia, yesterday gave tacit support to Labor's defence policy.
And at the same time, the RSL chief expressed reservations about aspects of the Liberals' defence policy.
In subsequent paragraphs, Louise Dodson reported:

From Sir William's point of view, it was an opportunity for some handy lobbying on defence issues.

I pointed out to Sir William in my subsequent correspondence with him that, as the head of a national body such as the RSL, it was inappropriate to be seen to be party politicking in the middle of an election campaign. TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT BILL 1990

The purpose of this Bill is to amend section 50, the mergers and acquisitions provision of the Trade Practices Act, to overcome an omission which has become apparent in the coverage of the provision, and to make several other improvements.

Section 50 prohibits acquisitions of shares or assets which result in a corporation either obtaining, or substantially strengthening, a position of dominance in a substantial market in Australia. In determining whether a position of dominance or strengthened dominance would result, the section permits the aggregation of market shares of companies that are related to or associated with the acquiring corporation. The section defines an associated body corporate in terms of one body corporate being in a position to exert a substantial degree of influence over another.

The Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission Professor Baxt expressed concerns that an aspect of the judgment in Trade Practices Commission v Australian Iron and Steel and Ors-the New Zealand Steel case-disclosed a deficiency in the merger provision. The case itself was settled, but in the course of a judgment on some aspects of the case, the Court expressed its views on the meaning of the words ``directly or indirectly'' in s.50 (1). This sub-section prohibits a corporation from directly or indirectly acquiring shares or assets in a body corporate if a position of dominance would result.

The Court interpreted the word `indirectly' as applying only to a situation where an acquisition was made by another entity as agent for the corporation. In other words it would not be an indirect acquisition by the corporation where a subsidiary or associated company acquired assets or shares in a target company in circumstances where it could not be said it was acting as agent for its controlling company. Accepting this interpretation, the question then is what action, if any, could be taken under s.50 to prevent an acquisition which might be structured through a subsidiary or an associated company. Where the subsidiary or associated acquiring company is itself a trading, financial or foreign corporation, action can be taken directly against it, with the market positions of all associated and related companies, including the holding or controlling company, taken into account in determining dominance. However where the acquisition is by a body corporate that is not a corporation action cannot be taken against it using the aggregation provisions. The insertion of the new s.50 (1aa) will plug this gap. There have been comments that the practical significance of the new provision would be very limited. The Government's attitude is that while the gap remains it could be taken advantage of, and that it has an obligation to ensure that this cannot happen.

The Government is taking the opportunity to put forward some other amendments to the section to improve its internal consistency. An infringement takes place where as a result of an acquisition the relevant acquirer would be or would be likely to be in a position of dominance or strengthened dominance. However the concept of likely effect is not consistently applied in the section and the amendments will remedy this. Also the section is not consistent in its reference to associated companies and again the Bill addresses this. In particular the proposed amendment to the aggregation provisions of subsection 50 (2) is designed to ensure that, in determining whether an acquisition is likely to result in a position of dominance, account can be taken of the aggregated market shares of the acquirer and its related and associated bodies corporate.

There have been some comments that these other amendments are unnecessary and could cause confusion. The Government notes that there is room for argument whether some of the amendments are strictly necessary, but it has acted following advice that it was desirable to clarify the meaning of certain expressions. It has taken the view that the better course is to avoid the possibility of any future dispute as to meaning.

In conclusion, the Government believes these amendments will ensure that Australian competition law as embodied in the Trade Practices Act continues to be effective, and that any window of opportunity available to exploit any weakness in the Act is firmly closed. The Bill is expressed to come into operation from 21 December 1990, the date of its introduction into the House of Representatives. It is considered appropriate that some retrospective effect be given to the measure, to ensure that advantage is not taken of the gap I have mentioned before the Bill becomes law.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to the Senate.
EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING AMENDMENT BILL
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988.

Among other things, that Act provides for the Higher Education Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training to report to Parliament on the operation of educational profiles and the impact of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme. Educational profiles are a mechanism designed to balance the freedom of institutions to manage their own affairs with the need for public accountability. They represent agreements negotiated annually between the Commonwealth and higher education institutions, defining an institution's broad mission together with its teaching and research responsibilities, and establishing its particular areas of activity and specified goals as the basis on which institutions receive Commonwealth funding.

The Higher Education Contribution Scheme, which came into operation in 1989, requires students and graduates to make a contribution towards some of the costs of the provision of their studies. At the time of the Scheme's inception, a provision was inserted in the Employment, Education and Training Act requiring the Higher Education Council, in February and August of each year, to report to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, and thence to the Minister and Parliament, on the operation of the Scheme and its effects on access to higher education, and the level and quality of post-graduate research.

This Bill amends that provision by requiring the Council to report only once each year, in March. The need for this amendment is straightforward. Late in 1990, the Board reported that the Council has experienced practical difficulties in reporting in a substantive way in August. At that time of the year, no firm data relating to higher education student enrolments in the current year is available, and the educational profiles discussions with institutions are not undertaken until later in the calendar year.

Accordingly, the Board proposed that the Council need only report once in each year, both on profiles processes and the impact of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme. March was recommended as the most appropriate month. By that time, final student enrolment data can be comprehensively analysed and the Council is in a position to comment substantively on the recently concluded profiles negotiations.

The Employment, Education and Training Act also provides for the Minister to appoint acting members of the Board and its constituent Councils for a period of up to twelve months in the event of a temporary vacancy. The intent of the Act was to provide for the circumstance where it is necessary for the Minister to appoint an acting member of a constituent Council who is also a member of the Board. Under the legislation as it currently stands, this option is not available to the Minister in all circumstances. The amendments are designed to remedy this deficiency and have no substantive policy or other implications.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 is an omnibus Bill that will make a number of largely non-contentious amendments to various Acts. The major amendments relate to borrowings of the Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory governments-and Senator Parer will deal with that shortly-to the control of the National Library land and buildings and to moneys payable to the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service from leases, licences, permits and other authorities, among other matters affecting the Australian Sports Commission Act, the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act and the National Library Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not be opposing these amendments, but we should point out at the beginning that this, in effect, will be the start of a whole host of Bills which, in one way or another, will correct the mountain of legislative mistakes that emerged last year as a result of the Government ramming legislation through the House of Representatives which, of course, as every honourable senator knows, had a record low number of sitting days.

Legislation was rammed through the House of Representatives without proper consideration. Then, having been starved of legislation for the first part of the Budget sittings, the Senate was inundated with a mountain of legislation. That means, of course, that we stayed here until 21 December, trying to correct the mistakes that this Government's incompetence had generated in that mountain of legislation. We are going to see now a whole host of Bills correcting mistakes. Included in this omnibus Bill is such a mistake correction exercise. Fear not; we will have plenty more to come.

I would like to deal first of all with the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. The amendment here will allow any money collected by the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service from leases, licence permits and other authorities to be used by the Service in its conservation role. The Opposition is quite happy with that proposal. Mr Dobie said in another place:

. . . since 1985, when the government parties set up the Australian Wildlife Fund, a non-profit company, it has helped to raise funds for the service to assist koala research and support research into endangered species. It is hoped on this side of the House that the Australian Wildlife Fund will continue its work in providing funds for research projects . . . this amendment may also provide further funding for similar research by the ANPWS.
Mr Dobie pointed out:

. . . no mention has been made of who will be appointed to the board of governors and whether they will be appointed without financial reward, as is the case with the Australian Wildlife Fund Ltd. This is a remarkable omission by the Minister.

The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), as Mr Dobie said, has had a lead from the annual report of the National Parks and Wildlife Service of the previous year, which, under the heading `Australian Wildlife Fund Limited', states:

The Australian Wildlife Fund Limited . . . is a non-profit company set up in 1985 to raise funds for research projects of the ANPWS. The AWF has a board of Governors who are prominent in business, community service or broadcasting and contribute their time to the Fund without financial reward.

In winding up the second reading debate, the Minister in the other place said that these remarks would be noted. We are still waiting for them to be conveyed to us up here, and I think some action should be taken.

The other matter I would like to raise about the National Parks and Wildlife Service amendment is one raised by Mr Webster in the other place. He pointed out that in many instances a shortage of funding has been the excuse for governmental bodies, not only Federal but also State, failing to take appropriate hazard limitation work-in other words, burning off-in appropriate times of the season in government wildlife areas to prevent bushfire disasters.

There are some people who are very concerned about this. I remember an article in the Sydney Daily Telegraph a few years ago which was headed `Politicians and ``greenies'' mean more Ash Wednesdays'. The concern clearly is that, unless there is effective work to get rid of the fire hazard in the national parks-and that does involve some burning off at appropriate times of rubbish that is collected-there will always be the prospect of disaster.

I do hope that some of the funds raised as a result of this amendment will go towards both research into this problem and, as a result of that, appropriate methods of convincing some extreme greenies-I think all of us are greenies to an extent-that there is benefit to the ecology of these areas in preventive work being done to ensure that we do not suffer devastating bushfires.

I would now like to move to the Australian Sports Commission amendment, whereby paragraph 48 of the Act is to be amended by the insertion of a subparagraph which will bring reports on the financial transactions of the Australian Sports Foundation under the reporting requirements of the Audit Act 1901. The Sports Commission had previously provided this information voluntarily in its annual report. The inclusion of this subsection follows a request from the National Audit Office.

The other day I expressed some concern about the delay that the Government is allowing, or in fact imposing, on the presentation of the Australian Sports Commission annual report to this Parliament. One of the requirements of good reporting is not simply that a report should be made, but that it should be made in a timely fashion. As I noted at that time, the Auditor-General had concluded his audit investigation by, I think, December of last year and had signed the audit certificate on 18 December 1990. We did not get it here until this month, March. As I noted at the time, Mr Harris, the Chairman of the Australian Sports Commission, had not put a date on his covering letter to the Hon. Ros Kelly, the Minister, so we do not know whether the delay was in the Minister's office or in the Australian Sports Commission. Wherever it was, they could smarten up their act.

The Australian Sports Drug Agency Act is being amended with minor alterations to correct drafting errors in the original Bill, but the meaning and application of the Act are not being altered. As I said, this is going to be one of the many correcting pieces of legislation, fixing up Bills which were rushed through this place and which have now become Acts with errors.

It may well be, of course, that the Government had not expected the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act to come in a timely way before the Senate, particularly when it was accusing the Opposition of having delayed it, which of course we did not. As a result, the Government had not prepared itself properly, and we saw a few minutes ago in the Advance to the Minister for Finance that no provision had been made for funding for the Australian Sports Drug Agency, and we have had to provide $280,000 to enable it to proceed. We have no objection whatsoever to this Act being corrected; we only wish the Government could get it right first time.

The National Library Act has a series of alterations which are of a minor technical nature, but there are some other sections that are being amended to bring the Act up to date. Section 7a, for example, will allow the Library to purchase and dispose of assets and to enter into contracts to a value of $250,000 without the need to obtain the approval of the Minister. This increases it from the previous value of $50,000, which had remained unchanged for 18 years. Under Labor governments inflation does seem to get out of control, and I presume that there is no alternative but to change such limits as existed in this Act to cope with Labor governments' incompetence in the area of inflation.

Sections 15 and 17e are being amended and a new section 15a is being added to remove the requirement that the Governor-General notify in the Gazette the vacation of office and resignation of members of the Council and of the Director-General of the Library. This is not a practice with other statutory authorities. In this context, I should say that we would have liked to move amendments to this Act and to the other Acts mentioned, removing the ageist bias that this Government continues to impose on council bodies like these.

We have on the Notice Paper a Bill that I have introduced in the Senate to get rid of the age limitation of 65 years that affects those serving on the councils of such bodies. At the moment the Government has a requirement that people over 65 cannot be members of such councils. The Bill that I have before the Senate relates specifically to the Australian National Maritime Museum. When the Maritime Museum Bill was before the Senate we failed in our attempts to get the Australian Democrats to support us to get rid of the age limitation, which in the case of the Maritime Museum is farcical. Some of the best people one would want on that council would be, for example, retired mariners, who may well to be over 65.

We have heard from the Government consistently that it is looking into the matter. One could call this a mirror image Government; it prefers to look into matters rather than do anything about them. I am very disappointed that the Australian Democrats are prepared to take the Government at face value and not to keep getting rid of this ageist limitation every time it comes up. The Government's defence on this matter is that it relates to Comcare, and that Comcare is not capable of dealing with people who are over the age of 65 if they break a leg or suffer some other injury in their employment as a member of such a commission or council. Of course, that is total bunkum because the Audit Act provides for act of grace payments for exactly this sort of thing.

We are all well aware of the fact that there are some bodies-and I recall that the National Museum is one of them-which have serving on them people who are over the age of 65. Certainly the Australian National Gallery has the capacity to have among its members people over 65. For example, until very recently Gough Whitlam was Chairman of the Australian National Gallery, even though he was well over the age of 65. I did not see the Government turning blue or the walls falling in or any other disaster taking place, except that Mr Whitlam kept attacking the Government for its incompetent handling of the National Gallery. That may have been the reason why the Government has taken the view that perhaps people over 65 should not be allowed on these boards because they may be inclined to speak their minds and attack the Government. In any event it is in our view improper that people over 65 should be excluded from membership of such bodies, particularly when there is plenty that they could contribute from their detailed experience in this area.

New section 21 will make provision for parts of the Audit Act to apply to the National Library to allow the Library to invest money which is held other than in trust and which is not immediately required to be invested with an approved bank, in Commonwealth securities or in any other manner approved in writing by the Treasurer. A further provision also allows regulations to be made for the supply of liquor on Library premises and will allow the Library to operate its catering facilities on a more commercial basis. Similar provisions apply in the National Gallery Act, the National Museum Act and the Australian National Maritime Museum Act. We strongly support the attempts by these bodies to raise what money they can from acting in a commercial and sensible way. I just hope that those bodies that manage to keep getting revenue are not penalised by the Government for their initiative, as is so often the case, and the amount raised in such activities taken off the amount of core funding that they should be getting.

New section 27b extends regulatory powers to control the movement of persons on Library land and buildings and will allow regulations to be made to prevent trespass to restricted areas. This also brings it into line with the other organisations of which I have just spoken. The final amendment to the National Library Act is to increase the maximum penalty for offences against the regulations from $100 to $500 and remove the reference to a prison sentence of up to three months. This also is in line with the others.

On the matter of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service amendments, there is real concern in the populace at large about the extent to which the forests which are within the Service's responsibilities in declared heritage areas are somehow excluded from any other use. There seems to be a total misconception in the public mind, I think generated largely by the heated nature of debate on this subject. The recent report of the Australian Forestry Council, which I mentioned earlier today, noted:
. . . the misconception generally held within the community, that the Commonwealth National Estate listings are equivalent to a land tenure status . . .
It noted:

the desirability for formal procedures for consultation with State Governments regarding implications of listing areas on the National Estate Register, and . . . the need for a rational and scientifically based approach to listing National Estate areas including clearly defined criteria; and
the need for guaranteed resource access either through formal Commonwealth/State arrangements or legislative provisions to facilitate major resource based project developments.

There is no doubt that the standard and status of the National Parks and Wildlife Service control and care of these areas have always been very high within the financial limitations imposed and the concerns that many people have about adequate bushfire control and firefighting. There seems to be a real need across this whole area for a much clearer understanding of the implications of Government actions. I guess that it will take more than amendments to this legislation to do it. It will need a committed and dedicated approach by this Government.

In conclusion, I would say that the Opposition has no objections to these amendments and it wishes them well, but we point out that when one legislates in haste, as this Government has done, corrections at great length will follow. This Bill encompasses some of those corrections, of which we shall see many more later this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill. This is an omnibus Bill which amends six Acts and repeals one. The aspects of the Bill that relate to the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) are those which I will address in this debate. As a consequence of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 a number of housekeeping pieces of amending legislation have been introduced as the Territory moves to fuller autonomy. In this instance there are two aspects which affect the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, section 73 of the self-government Act provides for the remuneration of members to be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal or enactment of the Legislative Assembly. There is currently a Tribunal determination in force and I understand there is conflicting legal advice as to whether the enactment could be made. Section 14 provides that a member vacates his or her office if the member:
takes, or agrees to take, directly or indirectly, any remuneration, allowance, honorarium or reward for services rendered in the Assembly otherwise than under section 73.

Given the conflicting legal advice in relation to those two sections, as well as the risk to members who may receive what could be un authorised benefits, the Opposition supports this amendment. The amendment to section 14 of the Act will entitle members of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly to legislate to establish a superannuation scheme for its members and their dependants.

Secondly, in so far as the legislation affects the Australian Capital Territory, repeal of the various borrowing provisions in the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 is a result of last year's Loan Council decision that the States and Territories will gradually assume full responsibility for raising and servicing their own debt. The repeal will not affect the Commonwealth's power under other legislation, current or future, to guarantee Territory borrowings-either the ACT or the Northern Territory-for special reasons, nor limit the borrowing powers of the Territories.

This legislation will remove standing provisions in the self-government Act which require the ACT Government and its statutory authorities to obtain the Commonwealth Treasurer's approval for borrowings which will also no longer be guaranteed. The definition of `borrowing' in sections 3, 61, 62 and 63 of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act will be repealed with effect from 1 July this year.

I turn briefly to the amendments as they affect the Northern Territory. This amendment, as indicated by the Northern Territory Government, will produce a financial disadvantage to that Territory in that it will increase the borrowing cost to the Territory through the withdrawal of the Commonwealth guarantee. While the amendment will no longer require the Territory to seek the Federal Treasurer's approval for its borrowings, it reduces the attractiveness of Territory bonds due to the loss of that guarantee. To date, the Territory has found it easier to market its bonds due to the Commonwealth guarantee as most investors are willing to pay a premium for such a guarantee.

The cost to the Territory will be quite significant, and an example can be seen through Telecom bonds. In February, Telecom non-guaranteed bonds were being issued at some 70 to 75 basic points, or 0.7 per cent, above the Telecom guaranteed stock. Such an increase in the Territory's cost of borrowing would add some $15m to $18m in total over the next five years. On the other hand, there is absolutely no cost to the Commonwealth in providing this guarantee. The Commonwealth's argument in withdrawing the guarantee is that it wishes to treat the Territory on a State-like basis. The Territory has advised that it would agree to this approach if other areas currently under the Commonwealth powers would also be transferred to the Territory as a matter of consistency; for example, uranium royalties, land rights and so on. As indicated earlier in this debate, the coalition will not oppose these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senators Baume and Parer for their contributions to this debate to which I will respond briefly. The Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill is probably most easily described as a modernisation Bill or a Bill to bring up to date various pieces of legislation under the auspices of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. This omnibus legislation will tidy up a lot of those pieces of legislation and will bring some up to date and, in fact, will repeal an out of date Act. Of course, I am particularly interested, wearing my constituency hat, in its implications for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), but they are, of themselves, not new. As Senator Parer said, they are the implementation of previous Loan Council decisions and their application to the ACT and the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the sports area and the National Library of Australia and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service: broadly described, the Bill is just bringing these organisations into line with modern public sector financial arrangements.

I welcome the support for the Bill and it would be a waste of the Parliament's time to reiterate those matters in which we are in agreement. But there are two matters which Senator Baume raised to which I feel the need briefly to respond.

He referred to the omission from the explanatory memorandum of material about a company called Australian Wildlife Fund Ltd. I know very little about that particular company, but I am advised that this company is not referred to in the explanatory memorandum, for the simple reason that this Bill does not deal with that body. It deals with the finances of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and money will be paid into a fund called the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Fund. But we need to distinguish that from a separate company entitled the Australian Wildlife Fund Ltd. The two are distinct and this Bill does not relate to the affairs of the Australian Wildlife Fund Ltd, as I am advised. Therefore, appropriately, it is not covered in the explanatory memorandum.

I heard that part of Senator Baume's contribution. I did not hear his reference to the question of age discrimination as it relates to the National Library, but I have heard Senator Baume speak on this before in other similar matters. We had a debate on a similar issue concerning the National Maritime Museum. The Government is, as he knows and as the Senate has been informed, examining this whole issue of age discrimination. It is very important. We do not wish to do it on an ad hoc basis; we are approaching it in as comprehensive manner as we can. Just to make it clear, there is-as I am advised-no age limit applying to members of the Council of the National Library. The age limit applies only to the Director-General and he is, of course, a full time salaried executive. The same arrangements apply to him as to other Commonwealth officers, and any change which takes place to age limits would be part of a comprehensive Commonwealth approach to change all such arrangements. So with those few remarks, I thank the senators for their support for the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
