TALK.START.PARA: —The Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill 1991 is only four pages long and comes with an equally small explanatory memorandum and a one-page second reading speech by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate). It is to this Bill that the Senate now gives its attention.

SPEECH.PARA: The explanatory memorandum that I referred to does not enlighten us in any detail as to the policy decisions that have generated the Bill. In fact, we are not much enlightened by the Minister's speech. We are certainly not enlightened by the background mess that the Government has placed the Chinese student program in, out of which this matter arises.

In particular, there is no admission so far by the Australian Government of the shambles that it has got Australia into in terms of our education institutions and the up to 20,000 Chinese citizens who are currently residing in this country. In the past two years some 5,000 of them-that is, a quarter of the number that was here in June 1989 when the Beijing massacre occurred, to which we had a Government response in this country-have, in fact, returned so there are about 15,000 remaining under the provisions of the decisions made at the time. In the original decision in July 1989 that extended the ability for these students to stay in this country, and in subsequent decisions, the Australian Government-the Australian Labor Party-has really created one shamble after another.

However, the Opposition does not oppose this Bill on account of that dreadful track record by the Australian Government in managing this matter. We believe that it is reasonable and acceptable to extend benefits to this group, to whom the right of extended residence in this country has been given at least until June 1993. It would be unfair and unreasonable to deny the benefits of access to the English language adult program that this Bill now gives to these Chinese students and other Chinese citizens in this country.

Whilst we remain highly critical of the Australian Government's conduct throughout the past two years, we think it is fair and reasonable, given that these 15,000 people are here with extended permanent residence in this country, that they have access to a program which will give them education in English and skills which they will need to take up the work opportunities that have now been extended to them. Let me make the Opposition's position clear: we do not accept the Government's policy decisions; we are critical of the Government's conduct of this matter; but we do accept this Bill as a benefit to the Chinese citizens who are residing in Australia.

This debate needs to focus on the mistakes of judgment by this Government, particularly by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I single out the Prime Minister not because he is the leading member of the Government-in fact, I have not singled out the Prime Minister for many months now-but because I believe that in the pattern of decisions that were made, particularly in July 1989, the Prime Minister himself ambushed his Government and over-promised what ought to be done. Much of the shambles that I referred to really lies at the Prime Minister's own feet.

Given the establishment of this category of people as having extended residence until 30 June 1993, it is reasonable that they have access to the English language and citizenship programs provided under the Immigration (Education) Act 1971. Thus, it is this Act that we are now seeking to amend by this Government Bill.

I remind the Senate of the history of this matter. There has been a series of ad hoc and unthought-out decisions concerning the People's Republic of China nationals in this country. On 6 June 1989 the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, announced the extension of temporary entry permits for Chinese nationals until the end of the next month-obviously a very temporary initial measure. This was followed by a 16 June announcement-10 days later-that the visas would be extended until 31 July 1990. That is an extension of about 13 months. Here in this chamber on 6 June, Senator Ray, the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, said-and these are his exact words:
Applications will not be determined on the basis of a class of people, but on individual merits. They will be considered on the basis of individual claims.
Those were the words in the undertaking given initially by the Minister.

However, whilst the Opposition supported those words that were initially given-and that remains our policy in this matter-the Government itself departed dramatically from those words in the few days that followed and that departure was, I believe, mostly the responsibility of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. It is a pity that the Government did not stick to the approach that Senator Ray had initially outlined. I believe that the Prime Minister would have been well advised to adhere to it but, instead, he announced in 1990 the creation of this special category for People's Republic of China nationals.

The Prime Minister has never been renowned for good judgment when it comes to matters of policy detail and, in this instance, he hijacked the policy processes of his own Government. I just speculate-and I am sure Senator Olsen, as a person who has taken a close interest in immigration matters, would speculate-what the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Ray, would have felt when he had given such an announcement and then the Prime Minister, over his head, announced a sweeping, en masse decision that, I suspect, did not have the support of that Minister. I say advisedly that the Prime Minister hijacked the Government's decisions. We all recall the way in which he left Ministers out of the decision making and let them scramble to catch up after he had made his announcement.

The decision that was eventually announced gave the 19,400 Chinese nationals in Australia before 20 June 1989 permits for temporary residence until 30 June 1993. This approach has been criticised by the Opposition ever since. We do not support the distortion of Australia's immigration program that the creation of this special category causes. Our policy is that each application should be considered on a case by case basis. We believe that there should be individual applications, or family applications where appropriate, and that those applications should go through due process and be considered on their merits case by case. It is not the Opposition's policy to force back any citizen of any country to an intolerable persecution in his home country. We share that with the Government.

We do not seek to let any individuals currently residing in Australia-whether students from China or any other country-go back to a situation where they do not have protection. In fact, we want international standards in human rights established in every country. That would be the surest guarantee that there would not be any unfair or intolerable persecution of individuals. But that general case still has to be demonstrated. I am sure that is what was in the Government's mind when it set the four-year period, mostly to be outworked through the effluxion of time.

I am sure that it was even the Prime Minister's consideration that by June 1993 there would be such a settling down of the great trauma arising from the massacre in Beijing in June 1989 that a great proportion of these 19,400 citizens of China would voluntarily and with an open conscience return to their own country. But that is not actually the policy that the Government has announced. It has not announced a case by case approach. It has announced an en masse extension of four years for a particular group from a particular country. To do that it needed to override immigration law and immigration regulations in this country. That overriding damages the integrity of the immigration program. It damages the public's perception of the integrity of that program.

When there are one million applications per year for permanent residence in this country, of course we have a filtering system, a selection process. Only 120,000 are eventually invited to take up permanent residence in this country. That is the immigration process. It is based on immigration law and immigration regulations. We want to give signals to the rest of the world, especially to those one million each year who apply to us, and all their families and sponsors and all those associated with them in this country, that we have a fair, objective, open, reliable immigration process. Then they see 19,400 people jump to the head of the queue and given an en masse promise to expect something very close to permanent residence-on the decision of our Prime Minister, overriding the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who was very sensible. I say `sensible' because he had demonstrated a track record for being sensible and because the task that he had, being the seventh immigration Minister in the Hawke Government, was to bring back some public confidence to immigration.

It was following the FitzGerald inquiry that it became transparent, if not in various tumults about Australia, that there was a need for public confidence in immigration. The surest way of gaining it was to demonstrate a reliable, fair, open, objective immigration process. When there is an upset to that reliability by this kind of decision, the integrity of the program is thrown to the four winds. That situation still is the case today. There has not been any recovery. There is still that damage done to public confidence in immigration. It is not sufficient for the Government to say that it can do all this and make all these exceptions purely on the basis of the human rights situation in China.

There is not time in this debate to give an account of the measures that have transpired in China over the last 18 months. I am not wishing to say-neither is the Opposition-that there are international standards in human rights in China. I have never professed that. Even last month, when I was advocating in the Senate that there be normalisation of relations between China and Australia, I suggested that we would be all the more able, I believe, to achieve a situation nearly approaching international standards in human rights by direct dialogue with China and direct representation of our views to representatives of China rather than by staying in silence in isolation from each other.

I do not accept exaggerated stories of all students overseas being at risk from intolerable persecution should they return to China. Clearly, nobody has been putting that view here in the Senate. There are some out in public who maybe have put that view. By and large, the public and all of us in the Senate need to look at the bona fides of that view and decide whether it is not in itself an exaggeration to make it easy for some of the Chinese nationals who just want to stay in this country as every one of the one million applicants do. We do not deny those good motives. They are to improve their life, to make a contribution to Australia and to enjoy the affluence of a modern, developed country. Anyone who visits China can see that it is a developing country with a much lower level of affluence than we enjoy in this country.

Many applicants from Italy, Greece, the Philippines and even from the Netherlands or the United Kingdom are wanting to improve their life outcome, be a part of a developed country and make a contribution to this country by bringing their own freshness and vigour to it. Good luck to them for all those reasons, but let there be objectivity in the selection process.

Because these matters are complex and because the actual individual situation of any applicant would need to be considered, the Opposition remains supportive of the view that this matter should be approached on a case by case basis. When I say that, obviously there would need to be guidelines in practice that would give officers of the Department, and even the applicants themselves, some ability to discern their chances of having what was required to differentiate their application as one that would be in the minority accepted or in the majority not accepted. There would need to be guidelines, but we believe that applications should still be decided on the basis of a case by case approach.

There have been other matters relating to China and immigration that the Parliament has had to be concerned with. We recall the problems that have arisen through inadequate Government policy governing the English language intensive courses for overseas students. Recruitment of students from China for such courses in Australia was halted by the Government in October 1989, a few months after the June events to which I have referred. That program was halted not for one month but for four months. There were no applicants at all, when there had been a pattern of more than 10,000 a year coming from China for English language study in this country.

In that process thousands of Chinese citizens had made the necessary preliminary payments to gain admission to courses in this country. Because their applications were no longer successful, millions of dollars had to be repaid to those students. Because of currency changes, the value of money now compared to the value of money then and the students being from all 26 provinces of China, the Government made an enormous problem for itself by its mismanagement through 1989 of the English language enrolments from China.

I mention China so much because the majority of the students coming for the English language courses were overwhelmingly from China. In fact, there were more students from China in these courses than from all the other countries put together. When applications were eventually reopened, the criteria had been changed to be more stringent. However, the damage, the confusion and the loss of reputation that this Government had caused had already happened. It was substantial on all three fronts. There were disturbances outside our Consulate in Shanghai when the students gathered as an angry crowd to demonstrate and express their sense of grievance. Some suffered financial penalties in having paid their fees in advance to institutions in Australia which were not in a position to refund the money readily. Indeed, Parliament had to pass legislation late last year-the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill-to remedy that situation and provide taxpayers' money to ensure that repayments were made to those entitled to them. Many of the deposits were made to private institutions and there was no mechanism in place which required those private institutions to refund the money. We passed that Bill which gave taxpayers' money back in proportion to that which was owed.

Let me take this opportunity to note that most of the administration of those refunds to thousands of students, amounting to more than $5m in regard to one group of students alone, has been handled by our serving Australian staff overseas. I wish to commend the administrative skill that has been shown by those serving Australians overseas, particularly in Shanghai.

I remind the Senate that the Government has also announced legislation, the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill, to try to clean up the private educational institutions to which I have referred. It was supposed to be very urgent legislation when we first saw it last year; that is how it was announced by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins. In fact, it has not yet passed through the Parliament. It has not even come up for debate in the Senate. It was originally put up without much consultation and it was wrong. It would not have achieved what the Government had determined. After more consultation and after many comments from the Opposition, it was redrafted and we may see it very soon. In fact, it will first be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. It will then come for consideration by the Senate.

The history of that Bill is symptomatic of the ad hoc, erratic decision making and the totally unsatisfactory way that the Government has gone about these overlapping areas of education and immigration as they affect China. On top of those two patch-up Bills already, we now have this third one. It is clear that the Bill before us is a necessity because of the earlier bungles, the shambles, that I spoke of.

Providing for people such as the Chinese nationals who are here on four-year temporary permits will itself put extra pressure on the English language and citizenship courses offered under the adult migrant English program (AMEP). The Government makes clear in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill that no extra money is required by the Bill and no extra money is provided by this Bill for the AMEP.

The access to the adult migrant English program that has been given by this Bill to 11,000 Chinese nationals is at the expense of other permanent residents of Australia who, ordinarily, have access to adult migrant English programs. Let us note that the program will not be expanded. There will be no extra places; there will be no extra money in the scheme. This, of course, can only mean that some of those presently eligible will be denied the opportunity to take part in AMEP courses. There are Government estimates that the number of temporary residents to become eligible under the AMEP could be as high as 11,000. That means that, to the extent that the 11,000 do participate, they will be denying that opportunity to the equivalent number of others. It is perhaps unfair in the respect that those being extended this access by this Bill will not necessarily remain in Australia, but those who will be denied access by their enrolment will certainly be permanent residents of Australia. I trust that those who administer the AMEP scheme will carefully take into account the priority of enrolments so that they are acting without discrimination and in the best interests of all applicants under the AMEP.

I note that the adult migrant English program is under pressure anyway. I remind the Senate of what was revealed in the report of the working party on post-secondary English language training published last December-only three months ago. That report refers to the estimate of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that there is a backlog of 50,000 to 60,000 people seeking placement in adult English as a second language programs. This Bill will make that backlog 11,000 more. But, given the resources that are available and the size of the program, there will be a shortfall and many will be denied access to the English language learning that they are seeking.

The Government is clearly not giving sufficient priority to funding this program. People are missing out at the moment, not to mention those who will miss out in the coming months as a result of this Bill. There is a sense of replacing some in the queue with others in the queue.

While this is not a general debate about the benefits of AMEP because our focus is on this particular Bill, I should at least refer to the fact that many of us in the Senate have taken a careful interest in the role of AMEP, and I would like to commend it. I believe that the program is a good one. It has a commendable history that goes back to the late 1940s. Honourable senators may know of my interest in initiating some eight or 10 years ago a Senate inquiry on a national language policy. The recommendations of that major Senate report are still being implemented by the Australian Government.

In that context, I note the importance of teaching English to children and adults, especially migrant Australians, so that they can have the full participation in the Australian community to which they aspire. It is good for harmony and for ensuring that we have an equal access society in this country. I commend the achievements of AMEP throughout its existence and I look forward to a positive outcome from the Government's consideration of the working party report to which I have referred.

There is one particular matter on which I seek information from the Minister handling the Bill. That is with regard to clause 10-the very last few lines of the Bill-which refers to non-government organisations. What is the Government's intention by this particular clause? It is not clear to me; it was not referred to in the explanatory memorandum, or in the second reading speech of the Minister. Will extra levels of expenditure be required? Will there be some revenue raising aspect? Which particular non-government institutions are involved? I leave this matter with those final questions. For the reasons that I outlined at the beginning, the Opposition supports this legislation, although we do not support the series of bungled policy decisions of this Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill, which, as has already been indicated, is a small Bill in size, amends the Immigration (Education) Act 1971 to provide the Minister with power to broaden the categories of persons who can avail themselves of English language and citizenship courses. There are also a number of other minor technical amendments. The Act is being amended to enable the Minister to arrange for courses to be provided to persons who hold temporary entry permits of a class specified by the Minister by notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, the adult migrant English program is open to permanent residents only. As I say, this alteration will allow temporary residents-that is, those who claim refugee status, those who are here on special temporary visas and humanitarian type visas-to enter the program. Some of these people, of course, will be eventually granted permanent status, but this amendment to the Act gives them access, while they are in the temporary status, to the adult migrant English program.

This program includes two aspects: English courses and citizenship courses. There is some effective overlap between those two types of courses because of the use of citizenship aspects in the teaching of English under the English course.

In this Bill there is also a very sensible and logical change which extends the lower age limit down to 18 years; it is 21 years under the Act as it now stands. Other minor amendments include welcome rephrasing of an Act which had its genesis in 1971 to better reflect the multicultural nature of Australian society and to avoid former assimilationist connotations. For example, `way of living of Australian people' becomes `ways of life in Australia'. The amending Bill also acknowledges self-government in the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

There is expansion of the itemisation of costs which the Commonwealth may meet to include the cost of student support services, for example, child-care and counselling. As has just been pointed out by the previous speaker, clause 10 of the Bill gives permission for the Minister to enter into arrangements with non-government organisations to provide adult migrant English services to or for those organisations. The Australian Democrats, too, have some questions about clause 10. It is very unclear what that actually means. I would like some clarification from the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) as to the organisations that are being referred to there and, specifically, whether this involves funding being removed from the technical and further education sector, where a good deal of funding is going, into private schools.

At this point we note that there is, in fact, no increase in funds attached to this amending Bill. That is somewhat disturbing, particularly in the context of clause 10, but also in the context of what is an extension of the reach of the adult migrant English program. Although on paper it is an extension, it is difficult to see, with the lack of increased funding, how that can be an extension to any further numbers of migrant people.

There are problems with this Bill, a Bill which the Democrats do support, but I want to make sure that we put on the record the problems as we see them. One of the problems surrounding this area is the way in which the whole matter of extended eligibility has been handled and, as I have already mentioned, the fact that there has been no additional appropriation to cover the costs. In the Minister's second reading speech, we are told that, in addition to asylum seekers from presumably a number of countries, extended eligibility applies particularly to People's Republic of China nationals who happened to be in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square incident on 4 and 5 June 1989; that is, specifically those who now have a special four-year temporary entry permit and whose spouses have been able to join them here. The Government estimates that figure at about 11,000 people.

The whole situation with these People's Republic of China nationals has been handled in a knee-jerk reaction, in an ad hoc manner, so that many of them do not know, and have not known for a very long time, where they really stand. I shall just briefly go over that history. On 6 June 1989, Senator Robert Ray, then the responsible Minister, announced the extension of temporary entry permits until the end of July 1989 for Chinese nationals legally or illegally in Australia as at 4 June. Senator Ray clearly stated that the applications for permanent status from these People's Republic of China nationals would be considered on individual merits. On 16 June, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced that the Government would extend the visas for another 12 months, until 31 July 1990. In June 1990 the Prime Minister announced a special category for the 19,000-plus Chinese nationals who were in Australia before 20 June 1989.

As a consequence, they could apply for permits for temporary residence until 30 June 1993. Chinese nationals arriving after 20 June 1989 were entitled to apply for refugee status under existing criteria. Thus, two classes of people were created: those with temporary automatic protection, whether or not they needed it or wanted it; and the others, such as Burmese, Iranians, Lebanese, Sri Lankans, Fijians, and Chinese nationals arriving after 20 June 1989. The flaw really was that the first group-those Chinese nationals who arrived before 20 June 1989-had to withdraw their claims for permanent residency in order to be entitled to benefits provided under the terms of the special four-year temporary entry permits. Those benefits included special benefits, family allowance, family allowance supplement, Medicare and English language training. In other words, it was an attempt to persuade these Chinese nationals to go for special temporary permits rather than seek permanent residence.

Now, albeit belatedly, the Government has moved to redress this situation in this legislation by extending eligibility to English language courses. All cases for refugee or humanitarian status should be considered on their merits. We must also remember the cruel and arrogant statement by the Prime Minister when he announced that the Khmer, the Cambodian, boat people were not political refugees and, therefore, could not have their cases for refugee status considered individually. Thankfully, the Prime Minister did later reconsider this position and the Determination of Refugee Status Committee is now able to make that assessment on that essential individual basis.

The definition of a refugee is an internationally agreed one. A refugee is a person who is persecuted for the reasons of race, religion, nationality, and membership of a particular social group or political opinion and who is outside the country of his or her nationality and is unable or, owing to such fear, unwilling to avail herself or himself of the protection of that country.

On 26 February this year Senator Gareth Evans announced that the Government had decided to remove the remaining economic and political restrictions on Australia's relations with China following the tragic events in Tiananmen Square on 4 and 5 June 1989, as there have been-and I quote him- `discernible improvements in the human rights situation in China'. So says Senator Evans.

With particular regard to the people I have spoken of in relation to this legislation, the concern is whether this change of Government policy will make it more difficult for those on special temporary entry permits, who have been encouraged to move to that status, to now achieve refugee status on the basis of the definition which I have already given. That is a matter of considerable concern to the Australian Democrats in the context of the change of Government policy.

The Democrats support this Bill, which extends the eligibility of access to English language and citizenship courses. We especially applaud the fact that it leaves the Chinese nationals with special four-year temporary permits less in limbo than they have been. However, we are concerned, as I have said, that there will be no additional funding by the Commonwealth to pay for, on its own estimation, an additional 11,000 people who may be seeking places. A recent report of the working party on post-secondary education training, to which Senator Teague has already alluded, identified deficiencies in resources and outcomes in English language programs.

There is a backlog of some 60,000 long time permanent residents of migrant background who have language difficulties and who do not have access to English language programs, and we have to ask whether this amendment is going to make any difference to that problem. This report again estimates that about 365,000 do not speak English well, or even at all, and that some 170,000 of these are in the work force now. In the matter of occupational health and safety alone, I would have thought that that had to be a major concern. It would be untenable for permanent residents to be ousted from class places by temporary residents. So obviously the question of funding is a critical one, and obviously funding must be increased.

I refer the Senate and people interested in this policy area to the alternative Budget put forward by the Australian Democrats at Budget time last year in which programs, including this particular program, were allocated a 30 per cent real increase-this in the context of a Budget which clearly demonstrated where the money was coming from, and even more clearly demonstrated where the priorities of the Democrats would be. It is the range of basic language programs under the national policy on languages that has high priority.

As I say, we are particularly concerned with clause 10, and I look forward to comments from the Minister on that. It would be extraordinarily regrettable if our public sector education should be deprived even further than it already is in this area. We definitely need some answers from the Government on a clause which is extraordinarily open-ended and non-explanatory. The fact that there is no reference at all in the explanatory memorandum to this clause must be addressed in the debate tonight.

The Democrats support this Bill. We have expressed our reservations about the ability of this amendment actually to provide greater access to more people. Although obviously increasing the categories of eligibility is a step in the right direction, we are concerned about the lack of allocation of additional finance. We will therefore be closely monitoring the operations, as we always have, of the adult migrant English program and will bring problems very clearly back to the Senate should they occur as a result of deficiencies we have already outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I spoke on the industry, technology and commerce legislation and tonight we are debating the Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill 1990. At first sight there would seem to be no similarity, but in fact both these Bills have been introduced to fight a rearguard action against the mess created by earlier Government decisions. It is becoming an extremely repetitive happening in this chamber that we are dealing with legislation which would never have needed to be introduced had the Government done its job properly-got its decisions right in the first place. Tonight's ill-considered Bill we owe to the tearful largess and political insecurity of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who, determined to show Australia generally and his Cabinet in particular who was in charge of the shop, made a spur of the moment decision-perhaps staring into the blue eyes of Jana Wendt. He announced, completely at odds with his previous Minister for Immigration, Senator Robert Ray, that four-year temporary entry permits would be granted to all People's Republic of China (PRC) nationals in Australia before the Tiananmen Square massacre-all 19,400 of them.

SPEECH.PARA: Out the window went Senator Ray's statement after Tiananmen Square that PRC nationals should be treated like any other applicant for refugee status. Senator Ray got it right when he said that applicants for refugee status should be determined not on the basis of class of people but on individual merit; that they would be considered on the basis of individual claims. Clearly, the Prime Minister had other ideas. The legislation we have before us tonight, while using all means it can in its terminology to disguise the fact, is to give the PRC nationals on the special entry permits access to adult migrant English courses and citizenship courses. The said courses are paid for by the taxpayers of Australia, and it is estimated that some 11,000 people may use the opportunity of the free education.

The Opposition is not opposing the legislation. In fact, it would be quite churlish to refuse access to education programs which could allow the PRC nationals to make a better contribution to our society while they are here. However, there are problems which I believe ought to be explored in this debate tonight in relation to English language courses, PRC nationals, and the Prime Minister's spur of the moment decision that they could simply block book a four-year position here because they were in Australia before Tiananmen. We would do well to remember that many of the students now happily making use of the Prime Minister's temporary permits, which gained them a legitimate extra four years in Australia, were already illegals. It needs to be said that they were illegals not because they were frightened of politics or reprisals back home but because they had made a deliberate decision to stay here illegally well before Tiananmen Square.

What the Prime Minister did was to create chaos by making legal some 4,000 Chinese illegals. Indeed, it is most ironic, given the subject of this legislation, how those students came to be illegal in the first place. Yes, we allowed them into Australia to study, and of all subjects, English. Many of them came to be illegal by falsely declaring they were in Australia to learn English, with absolutely no intention of returning home after paying for, but in some instances-many instances-never attending, a short term language course under the English language intensive courses for overseas students (ELICOS) program. Others attended a few lectures in a small amount to look legitimate. The figures are quite staggering. From the start of the ELICOS program in 1986 until Tiananmen Square in 1989, only 10 per cent of the 16,517 Chinese students who entered Australia to learn English ever went home. Thousands of students, the majority of whom were Chinese, were literally buying their way into Australia posing as English language students.

There are reports of English language schools deliberately overenrolling because they knew that many Chinese students would not be attending lectures. Senator Ray, while Minister for Immigration, was reported in the media as calling the ELICOS scheme the English language intending change of status scheme. He was right. But in the end it was not ELICOS but the Prime Minister who did it for us. Despite all the evidence that each case for refugee status should be treated individually, despite evidence that many nationals would be in no danger in returning to China, they were all given the four years grace.

Now, courtesy of tonight's legislation, some 11,000 PRC nationals will be able-at Australian taxpayers' expense-to have English language lessons, the very subject many of them used and abused as a cover to enter Australia illegally in the first place. I hope that the irony of that is not lost on anyone listening to this debate. They are to take up places funded, we are told, out of current appropriations; previous speakers tonight have referred to that.

With our Budget appropriations this year, we have a disappearing surplus-the $8 billion surplus is evaporating day by day. It is fairly clear that next year Australia will have a substantial deficit. Yet, with this legislation opening up and guaranteeing these places with no appropriation of funds to account or provide for them, how are they going to be paid for? The surplus is evaporating. We will obviously be in deficit next year and yet we are putting in place a program that will have additional costs. Who will bear those costs and how? The Government's silence is deafening. Senator Powell and Senator Teague referred to that aspect and it is certainly incumbent upon the Government to identify to the chamber how the program will be paid for. Surely in today's economic climate, that is a legitimate and responsible question. The responsibility rests with the Government to reassure the chamber as to how the funds will be provided.

It should also be mentioned that while many of the PRC nationals on temporary permits are now getting a second, but this time free, opportunity to learn English, the under-resourced program is struggling to cope with a backlog of some 50,000 to 60,000 longer term residents with language difficulties who have requested some help. The adult migrant English program is quite clearly unable to cope with its present workload. As well, there are an estimated 170,000 overseas born permanent residents without English language at present in the labour force.

In its list of priorities the Government, as usual, is on the wrong track. I would have thought that at a time of economic crisis and faced with an under-resourced program, we have far more responsibility to our permanent residents than to those visitors on one-off temporary permits to study here for four years.

I repeat: the Opposition does not oppose this Bill but I call into question the Government's decisions from the day the Prime Minister, with knee-jerk emotion and without good sense, let some 19,000 Chinese nationals, many of whom had already overstayed their welcome, remain in Australia without individual assessment. That made a mockery of our immigration regulations as this legislation makes a mockery of our immigration education priorities.

We need to consider and ought not to forget that we have thousands upon thousands of people who are prepared to apply to become migrants to Australia and who are prepared to abide by the rules and regulations. They do not want to jump queues or squeeze in in front of other legitimate cases. Yet here we have the Prime Minister and the Government acting in a way that gives credence to those who jumped the queue; many of whom did so when coming to Australia with illegal intent in the first place. The Government's priorities are clearly wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their contribution to this debate. One of the major points raised tonight by all honourable senators who participated in this debate is the question of how longer term settlers in Australia may be disadvantaged by allowing People's Republic of China (PRC) nationals with four-year temporary permits to access the adult migration English program (AMEP). The Government has in fact recognised the problem of the under-resourcing of the AMEP and also notes that this continues to be an issue for recently arrived migrants with English language difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: The working party on post-secondary English language training also recognised there was a backlog of English language training needed for longer term residents as well. The issue is being addressed in the context of the development of a White Paper on Australian language and literacy policy. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is participating in the development of this policy and has developed this paper so that the Government can receive the fullest possible input from both recent and longer term residents in Australia as to their English language needs.

As has been mentioned tonight, not all PRC nationals with four-year temporary entry permits will be eligible for the AMEP course. The majority who have studied at English language intensive courses for overseas students (ELICOS) institutions are not entitled to access to these courses. Those who are eligible for the AMEP access will not be accorded any priority over other clients, whether long or short term. The focus of the AMEP is on client need because of the recognition of the importance of English for people to function effectively in our society for their period of residence.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —During my contribution to the second reading debate I asked the Minister on duty to give some explanation for the last clause of the Bill. I refer to the reference to non-government organisations in clause 10. There is quite a new reference to services for non-government organisations but there is no reference to these non-government organisations in the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) or in the explanatory memorandum. I, therefore, ask for an explanation of this clause. Secondly, are there any expenditure implications or revenue raising implications? What kinds of non-government organisations are referred to or are intended to be encompassed by this part of the Bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for not responding to the concern raised by Senator Teague. The explanation is quite simple: I was dragged down here with 30 seconds notice; I did not expect to come on duty until 9.30 tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been provided with the following advice for Senator Teague in reference to clause 10 of the Bill: this clause, which provides for the Minister arranging services to or for a non-government organisation, is for the purpose of giving program flexibility in responding to gaps in service delivery which cannot be met by current Australian migrant English program (AMEP) teaching centre networks-for example, in isolated areas and also in areas of high migrant settlement, and potentially to organisations offering preembarkation courses.

I am informed that Senator Powell also raised the issue of clause 10 and expressed concern about the Government not diminishing the public sector. This is a reference to a Government decision announced in 1990 to tender a portion of AMEP funds to a comprehensive tender and Ministers have now agreed to conduct an extensive review of the impact of tendering before proceeding.

DEBATE.TITLE: EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Employment, Education and Training Amendment Act 1988 is to be amended to achieve two new minor amendments: firstly, to give flexibility in making certain appointments to the board and councils; and, secondly, to bring together a pattern of twice yearly reports with regard to the board and its councils rather than an annual report, more particularly with regard to profiles and the higher education contribution scheme, commonly known as HECS. I will come to both those matters of substance in this brief Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As this is one of the rare opportunities for us to evaluate the Commonwealth Government's handling of higher education in this country, on behalf of the Opposition I will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill, which I will read out in a few minutes. Very sadly, it indicates the Opposition's view that this Government has a deplorable record in the handling of higher education in this country, particularly during the 3 1/2 years of tenure of the current Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins. Despite my high hopes and my respect for Mr Baldwin, it has not been much assisted since Mr Baldwin's appointment last year as the Minister directly involved in decisions in the higher education area.

We have before us a relatively small amending Bill, which is just another step along the path for the Labor Government in the period in which Mr Dawkins has been the Minister. The last 3 1/2 years have been a time of substantial change for the higher education sector. I describe it as change, not reform. I do not believe that we have advanced during this time. If I am pressed, I would say that we have seen some additional resources, but there has not been an increase in real terms of allocated public moneys per enrolment; there has been a decline every year of the Hawke Labor Government despite some of the propaganda that it tried to put about, particularly in the earlier part of its period in office. The change that has been brought about, summarised in Mr Dawkins's program by the White Paper that this Government has published, has been greeted with apprehension, discomfort, criticism and opposition by staff and students in higher education institutions.

I cite the imposition of profiles and the forced amalgamations of institutions, the arbitrary benchmarks that were set out in the White Paper, which have guided, like some robot, the policy decisions of this Government. I look at the failing resources in higher education and the mess, the disrepair and the shabbiness of our universities compared with 10 and 20 years ago.

There is need for reform in higher education in this country. The Opposition calls for reform. We have published alternative approaches for higher education that will free it up and bring choice, diversity and excellence and, above all, that will bring back genuine autonomy to our education institutions. It is with real sadness that in yet another education Bill before us, the Opposition must refer to the deplorable record, to the missed chances and to the damage that has been done in these past 3 1/2 years. I sometimes despair.

One matter that is very much in the interests of all senators-especially Senator Reid, my colleague sitting near me in the Senate who represents the Australian Capital Territory-is that yet another forced amalgamation, a forced rearrangement of structure has been thrust by this Government upon the Australian National University (ANU) for consideration and by the Chairman of the Higher Education Council who was appointed by this Government. Professor Chubb seems to have been completely absent from public debate and even from his colleagues on the staff of universities in the last two years. He has dared to put forward proposals which would dismember our proud national universities.

I have in front of me the ANU Reporter, the regular newspaper of the Australian National University, dated 27 February 1991-less than two weeks ago. It has the following headline `Chubb proposals would dismember ANU'. The article refers to Professor Chubb, the Chairman of the Higher Education Council, appointed by this Labor Government. According to the Council, the staff, the students and the residents in this city and those who care about the great tradition that has been established in the Australian National University, his proposals would dismember and restructure the ANU. TALK.START.PARA: —Chubb is locked into the Government.

—I think that Senator Michael Baume is right in his statement. I think that unless we, in the time available to us two or three times a year, protest and protest clearly this kind of nonsense, we will see it repeated more and more. We have a record now of 3 1/2 years of this sort of damage. I see only two Government senators in the chamber. I want honourable senators who are in their rooms watching the television version of this debate and the Australian community to know with great clarity that the Opposition deplores the record of this Labor Government with regard to higher education and, in particular, deplores the policies of the Minister, Mr Dawkins, and I am afraid his very quiet and non-dissenting ally, the new Minister, Mr Baldwin.

SPEECH.PARA: We make the plea `Keep your hands off higher education. Let them get on with their own decisions'. After all, not only have the decisions outlined in the White Paper, the centralist approach of an interfering Canberra, been deplored all around the country for two or more years, but also before that we have had 15 years of what I would call rationalisation, even during the time when my Party was in government-during the Fraser Government period. What was common to that 15 years was the chairmanship of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission of Professor Karmel.

I actually call these 15 years the Karmel years. I greatly respect Professor Peter Karmel because of his leadership in higher education. By his contribution, he has had more impact for good in this country than any other individual, including all of us in this Chamber. The Karmel years had a tendency to rationalise. There were some amalgamations, there was some clarification of which curriculum was best undertaken by which institution, and there were guidelines that were established that did bring about a very sensible approach to our higher education institutions.

We had an end to the anomalous situation where colleges of advanced education were not allowed to be involved in research or in some post-graduate degrees-I believe unfairly when they had the expertise in some departments to do so. That situation has now been made more sensible by providing all higher education institutions with the ability and the access to make bids for research moneys and higher education enrolments.

Even with all the Karmel years-these 15 years of rationalisation-surely the time has come when we can allow individual institutions their autonomy to make their own decisions. After all, they are the ones that are serving their own particular communities, they have community representatives on their faculty boards or on the university councils, and they also are very aware of what competing institutions are offering not only in their own States but across the nation.

I believe that we will get the kind of creativity and the kind of new initiative required in this country if we give the universities of Australia their autonomy so that they can take their own initiatives. I do not believe we will have such a free-for-all that there will be massive duplication or waste. In fact, by the very nature of competitive enrolment, limits will be placed on duplication to the extent that that is harmful.

I believe that instead of going down this track of damage in the Dawkins period, we should have been going entirely in the other direction. After the Karmel years, after that consolidation, we should allow for new creativity. There is a time to gather together and there is a time to allow opportunity for new activities.

It is a refrain which the Opposition has put now each session of Parliament and I do so again with the same vigour, with the same concern. I know that all through our universities we have increasing numbers of staff and students who are waiting for the day when the Opposition can be in government and we can see some of the policies that we have announced actually start to bring the remedies that we are looking for. The remedies are not going to be dreamt up here in Canberra. The remedies and the new initiatives will come from the staff and the students, the communities of those universities themselves, and our policy is to just open the doors to allow that to happen. We refer to the failures of the Labor Government in our amendment which I now formally move:
At end of motion add: ``, but the Senate deplores the Government's continued mismanagement of higher education, and in particular, it deplores the Government's:
(a) increasing interference in higher education through the intrusive educational profiles process;
(b) failure to provide a proper framework for accountability with respect to the exercise of Ministerial discretion;
(c) failure to provide adequately for independent policy advice;
(d) policy of forced amalgamations, the disruption it is presently causing in Victoria and the ACT and the damaging pressures it has created towards institutional uniformity;
(e) failure to provide institutions with the freedom and flexibility needed to address the impending shortage of academic staff;
(f) unsatisfactory imposition of the Higher Education Contribution charge on full fee postgraduate courses; and
(g) failure to make inroads into the level of unmet demand''.

There are nine specific charges that the Opposition puts to the Government of the day, and we call upon all senators to consider these charges. I have only a few minutes to give an indication of examples that lead us to these charges, that lead us to make this sad assessment of the deplorable way in which the Government has managed higher education in this country, and I look to all senators to give their consideration and support to this motion. By supporting it, we will bring very clearly to the Australian Government the need for redress of these problems.

As I outlined, the Bill contains two particular provisions. The two changes are quite acceptable to the Opposition and it is for that reason that, whilst we have this quite significant second reading amendment, we will allow the Bill a second reading and will support the committee stages of the Bill with two related committee stage amendments that I will be moving on behalf of the Opposition.

The Senate will remember that three years ago the Opposition amended the Bill, against the then Government's wishes, to have twice a year reporting on two matters, that is, on what was happening with education profiles. Every educational institution and university was required to submit to this centralist Labor Government an outline of its objectives, its profile, and it would get its funding from this Government to the extent that that profile, those objectives, and that plan were acceptable to this centralist Government.

Therefore, the profile system was a means of dialogue for Canberra to push around those education institutions. We have been thoroughly dissatisfied, as have academics throughout the whole country, with the way in which this has interfered with and intruded upon their own decision-making.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course. They have not had to account for years what they do with the money.

—The Minister, Senator Collins, is objecting. Let me make it quite clear to him and to every other Government senator that we do not believe that all wisdom resides in two Ministers in Canberra or in one group of even well intentioned public servants. We believe that the education decisions in this country should be built upon the knowledge, the experience and the initiatives of thousands of people involved in higher education in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, when there is discussion about funding and about what the objectives should be, it should be done openly and not behind closed doors, not where there is some ability for a Minister or his department to nobble the institutions, to get them to set out the kind of plan and the kind of objectives that happen to be acceptable to that tiny minority of persons, either Ministers or others close to the Minister in this Government. That is why this profile process has led to such disagreement and led to such dissatisfaction in the Senate. We wanted the National Board, through the Higher Education Council, to examine twice a year how HECS was going and to bring a report to us.

Over the past three years we have found in practice-and Senator Collins, as a former Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, will be interested in this-that the average time for the tabling in the Parliament has been two months after August and after February of each year.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer to the track record of Minister Dawkins with regard, for example, to Estimates committees. I have little to say about the new flexibility that the Bill before us will give for the appointment, particularly dual appointments or temporary appointments, of persons to be members of the councils and the Board. The new flexibility is entirely sensible and we support that aspect of the Bill.

In regard to the Opposition's second reading amendment, let me say on the third item-I have already covered the first two, perhaps too painfully for the two Government senators who are in the chamber-that it refers to the failure of the present Government to provide adequately for independent policy advice. I have considerable respect for the individuals who serve on the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and indeed for those who serve on the four councils-higher education, schools, training, and research-which serve under the Board. The experience of the members of the councils and Board is very considerable and those members have a lot to bring to the tasks covered by those bodies. But the Board and the councils are structured by the government of the day and are appointed to a pattern that serves the purposes of the government of the day and they do not have an independent secretariat sufficient to meet the secretarial needs in order that the councils and Board may flourish. They so much rely on the Department itself, which is totally answerable to and directed by the Minister, that they have yet to demonstrate that they are an independent source of policy advice to the government of the day.

During the period in which the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) and the Commonwealth Schools Commission existed, both under the Fraser Government and the early part of the Hawke Government, this was not a frequent criticism. Most of us had confidence that the Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission, for example, were not only made up of council members who were appropriately appointed experts, but were given terms of reference, powers and resources to be able to fulfil their role with independence. When they brought their reports to the Minister and, through the Minister, very quickly to this Parliament we saw those as independent council reports not only to the Minister but to the Parliament, to the public and to the education institutions themselves. In fact, the education institutions or universities could in a sense own the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. If that Commission were not summarising what those individual universities believed was in the best interests of this country, they could in their twice a year dialogues with CTEC get this independent body to be more persuaded of their view. That view would be tabled as the report of that more independent council.

Of course, the government of the day has the ultimate say as to what the policy will be, but often in the past 20 years a comparison has been made, even on a yearly basis, between what CTEC found, advised and recommended, on the one hand, and what the Government was able to do, on the other hand. Often it was a question of saying, `We do not have the kinds of resources available to do all that CTEC has recommended'. But in this case NBEET and the councils are hand in glove with the Minister and this Government. I am not saying anything that is a secret to members of NBEET. I have met them in the rooms that house the National Board and the councils and I have made this point to them face to face. I am not free to say what those individuals had to say in response to me, but it does not take too many minutes for any senator in this chamber to see which is the more dignified, the more self-respecting approach for anyone who is on a board or a council to give national advice on education. They will want to have the resources, their own secretariat, to be able to carry out their researches with independence and to bring independent advice to the Australian public as much as to the Government, with the knowledge, the realism, that not every aspect of their advice will be followed by the government of the day. I believe that we are long overdue a review of NBEET and the councils that will achieve that kind of independence.

I see Senator Bell, the Australian Democrat spokesman on education, in the chamber. I say this openly because we expect to be in government in less than two years time, and hasten the day: the only thing that is going to save higher education is a change of government. That is the only thing left now. I am saying, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, not only to Senator Bell but to all honourable senators in the chamber: let us see, in the new era for higher education that will come after the next election, a genuinely independent council that will give advice on higher education, on the Commonwealth's involvement in schools, on training and on research and a council that will not easily be typified as being in the pocket of the Minister or confined and restricted from giving the kind of advice that this country needs. Education is the greatest investment that we can make into the future of this country. We are not looking just at the length of this Parliament, we are looking 25 and 50 years ahead, and we must make sure that from these debates we get the best possible education provisions in this country.

One of the things Senator Teague mentioned in an earlier speech today was the ad hoc, erratic decision-making process, as he described it, which has been undertaken by this Government in relation to the overlapping areas of overseas student immigration and education. My suggestion is that a similar adhockery applies to the overlapping areas of education, youth, employment, training and assets testing for benefits which are paid. This whole area is fraught with inconsistencies, unintended consequences, poverty traps, and plain outright injustices. They have been caused by schemes and bureaucracies which do not, honestly, satisfactorily coalesce. I agree with the observation by Senator Teague about the earlier Bill, but in this particular instance we can see a tendency for adhockery to apply again.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not spend a lot of time describing what this Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill proposes to do in changing the reporting requirements of the Higher Education Council from twice to once a year, in March, or about its other provisions. In fact, the Australian Democrats will not be opposing the Bill. But there are many concerns about the Government's approach to higher education in Australia. I will take this opportunity to outline some of the worst case scenarios that have resulted from this Government's misdirection in this area. For example, one of the subjects of this regular reporting by the Higher Education Council is the effect of the operation of the higher education contribution scheme (HECS).

The Democrats will continue to oppose the imposition of tertiary fees. It is our belief that students already forgo income and generally end up paying higher taxes. But the benefits of education accrue to the whole of society. It is the whole of society which has the responsibility for educating its citizens with equity and equal access.

At this stage, some of the evidence we have about the application of the higher education contribution scheme is anecdotal. It really is a hard task, in evaluating the effect of the application of HECS, to actually ask a group of people-those who are not here-to put their hands up. But that is, in fact, one of the things one would be required to do to find out who was discouraged from tertiary education participation by HECS. According to the information available to the Australian Democrats, it is patently obvious that the imposition of tertiary fees excludes many people from higher education, regardless of their ability and aptitude. It is purely according to their financial means.

Students who manage to pursue their studies but cannot afford to pay up front must pay a penalty of 15 per cent. The poorest students are further penalised by the Budget changes which were recently introduced and which increased the rates of payments of the deferred higher education contribution scheme. These accelerated payments are regressive. In other words, people falling within the lowest income bracket now pay at a rate 100 per cent greater, and those in the highest bracket only pay at a rate 25 per cent greater. So much for equity and access in education. Despite all this rhetoric we so often hear about building a clever country, Commonwealth funding for higher education is still less than one per cent of our gross domestic product.

Another new measure which is unacceptable is the Government's ruling that fee-paying, postgraduate students who are trying to upgrade their skills must pay at least twice the amount of HECS at the up-front rate. This burden makes a mockery of this Government's so-called commitment to further education as the key to Australia's future. The students participating there not only forgo earnings but generally pay their own fees rather than have their fees in postgraduate studies paid by parents, employers or somebody else or through some other award. In that situation, we are talking about postgraduate students who are often mature students. Apart from the course and living expenses, including consequential child-care costs, many of these people are part timers who do not receive Austudy, so it really is a double bind.

I turn to Austudy. The Government's Austudy scheme is totally inadequate. There are a number of concerns regarding Austudy. Among the major problems are the changes to the spouse income test. The age of independence is 25 years. That is the governing age according to the regulations on independence. Another concern is the continuing disparity between Austudy and unemployment benefit for people over 21. The stringent tests on income and assets mean that Austudy is only available to the very poor. For instance, just to define that phrase `very poor', the threshold under the spouse income test has been reduced from over $18,000 a year, which was not generous in anybody's language, to $12,150 a year. That is what the spouse can earn to allow the student to be eligible for any Austudy payments whatsoever. That amount is actually less than the current poverty line for couples with one person in the work force. Including housing costs at the moment, that is $13,015 a year. So one has to be defined as very poor to even be eligible for Austudy and then has to trot off and do one's best to enhance one's qualifications. It is much less than half the average gross income of over $29,000 as at August 1990.

The spouse income test effectively excludes thousands of people, especially married women, from further study. For those who continue, many more couples will be forced into poverty during their student years. So really, the amount of Austudy, even after qualification, is totally inadequate. Under Democrat policy, we would see that reviewed immediately. According to our policies, student allowances should be set at 120 per cent of the poverty line and indexed to the consumer price index, as a very minimum. For some people over 21, it is still better to receive unemployment benefit than to try to study, with the lower payments of Austudy. Of course, that is very difficult to organise and almost impossible to continue to apply.

On paper the figures suggest that a student who attempted to do that would be better off-to be defined as unemployed and receive that benefit rather than to be defined as being engaged in full time study and receive the Austudy benefit. Of course, that discrepancy continues to discourage people from studying. For instance, a single adult aged 18 years or over receives $60 a week more on unemployment benefit than a student between 18 and 25 years of age who still lives at home.

The problem of insufficient Austudy is compounded-I spoke earlier of the double bind-by the recession and the lack of part time work which is traditionally necessary for students to pay for those expenses which are difficult to quantify but which are obvious and necessary, such as living expenses, the present exorbitant textbook prices and the increased student union dues, which this year have gone up by about 15 per cent. Even if students were able to supplement their meagre Austudy income, which they are allowed to do only to a very tiny degree, the recession has meant that the opportunities for part time work have dissolved along with many other things. At the moment, those who are trying to survive on Austudy are finding it very difficult to meet the sorts of expenses necessitated by being a student.

The next problem in this area is the unmet demand for tertiary places. With the picture I have just painted, one would wonder why anybody would want to attempt to be a student. Nevertheless, with very poor job prospects more students are completing year 12, having been encouraged to do so by this Government-and rightly so-and qualifying for tertiary admission. However, the Government has failed dismally to provide enough places for those students.

Initial estimates from the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee show that the level of unmet demand this year is roughly five per cent higher than last year, with worse figures for Queensland. Nationally, this means that up to 21,000 students have missed out on tertiary places. So far, the figures show that in Victoria, for instance, a record number of students have missed out, with applications exceeding enrolments by almost 9,000. In Queensland, a State with one of the highest levels of unmet demand, the excess of applications over enrolments is 26,000. In South Australia, over 11,000 applicants-more than one-third of the total-received no offer of a tertiary place at all. The pattern is repeated throughout Australia.

Of course, these are only initial figures; of course, there will be multiple applications; and, of course, some students will change their minds. But it is inexcusable for this Government to encourage young people to stay on at school, to pretend to value higher education and then to dump thousands of qualified school leavers throughout the country in this way. I am tempted to throw in the meaningless phrase `clever country' again, but I am starting to feel dizzy every time I hear it because it is a nonsense phrase now, and demonstrably so, and this legislation will do nothing to add to the process of our becoming a clever country. What is needed is that this unmet demand be met. Until some sort of effort is made in that regard nobody has any right to utter that phrase again in this place, and I will resist the temptation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is if you assume that all collective wisdom is contained in the universities, with respect.

SPEECH.PARA: The academic shortage which helps to deny young people that opportunity also concerns us. It seems that the stage has been reached where this Government can no longer ignore the increasing shortage of academic staff. Predictions being made of an acute shortfall of up to 25,000 in potential academic staff by the end of this decade are horrifying. The report by Dr Blandy and the National Institute for Labour Studies on the academic labour market suggested a national shortage of up to 19,000 academic staff by the end of the decade, and other studies contain worse predictions. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee predicts a shortfall of up to 25,000 academics by the year 2000.

It is a case of the Government needing to act quickly to encourage more students to pursue post-graduate studies and to recruit and train academic staff. At the very least, the Government must extend HECS exemption scholarships to cover everybody doing a masters and PhD course-including part time students who are involved in those studies-and certainly look towards including many more honours degree and graduate diploma students. That is the very least position for HECS exemption. The Democrats' policy is to continue to push for the abolition of HECS.

The number of post-graduate research awards should also be further increased. The Democrats believe that the number and value of course work awards should also be increased, with academics coming up through this track as well as through the traditional research route. But that would not be enough on its own. This amalgamation business must be addressed. Although Senator Teague went into detail about the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and what is proposed there, I do not intend to address that in detail tonight. I will say in passing that the Federal Government has clearly disregarded the previously promised voluntary nature of higher education amalgamations. The evidence so far has suggested that this amalgamation process has been costly in educational and financial terms, and that it would be more satisfactory to have a client driven approach to restructuring higher education. That would be much better than what we see at the moment, which seems to be a mania for amalgamation for its own sake. The amalgamation mania, without justification, has led us to what is a ludicrous situation in the ACT, where the justification for pursuing such a course has not been made on educational grounds but simply because it seems to be a good idea. The bureaucratic and financial drivers are at odds with the institutional justification, and certainly this does not seem to fall into the category of being a voluntary amalgamation between campuses.

The Democrats believe that individual campuses must be encouraged to develop their own strengths and diversities, and that access to suitable housing is the way to approach this from the grassroots level. So often there is criticism of individual institutions for either the area that they service or the hinterland that their students come from. It seems to have escaped the Government that student mobility and access to institutions is directly a function of the available housing in the area. There is a crisis in student housing, and it needs to be addressed. Higher education in Australia continues to suffer from this lack of mobility. It is our belief that access to reasonably cheap good standard accommodation is entirely the key to student mobility.

The opportunity to stay at residential colleges seems to be something which is not part of the Government's policy in this area at all. This is what I referred to earlier. There is an adhockery about the Government's approach to benefits, to accommodation and to the youth policy of the nation as a whole. Education seems to be a separate little box. Well, it is not. It is part of the fundamental question of accommodation, sufficient funding, sufficient previous education and sufficient motivation to participate in tertiary education. The situation now is that there is a shortage of places in residential colleges. Many students have to pay high private rents or even forgo tertiary studies-this is especially a problem for students from country areas.

I would like to repeat the call that I have made previously: for the Federal Government to establish single, multiple and family dwellings both on and off campus which can be used by students and which would be available at either low interest loans or under commercial arrangements; and to provide low cost housing on and off campus as well. By providing such affordable accommodation at all tertiary institutions, at least the Government could then look towards the students following through and studying at institutions which best serve both their needs and the country's needs. There would not be the situation that is so often criticised at the moment where duplication of courses occurs in nearby campuses. `Nearby' might be only a matter of a couple of hundred kilometres but, without the provision of suitable accommodation, students will not be mobile.

We might get somewhere if we have some appreciation of the need for consistent, interrelated, relevant policies which cover not just one sector of those matters concerning young people but all of the areas-so that when a person turns 18, 23 or 25 a poverty trap is not created and a decision-making process, which brings about a disadvantage to that person, through no fault of his own but through the fault of inconsistent and illogical government policies, can be avoided.
