What Senator Bolkus does not understand-and I wish he did understand-is that when we are talking about allocating additional places upon the basis of population growth, we must talk about population growth. We cannot talk about allocating places on the basis of population growth and then compare it to the percentage of the population. I intend to do what Senator Bolkus should have done this afternoon which is to look at the growth figures.

Some interesting statistical growth figures for towns of approximately the same size as Cairns, that have university campuses, are very revealing. For example, Townsville which in 1986 had a population of some 106,000 people had an annual growth rate of 1.9 per cent. If we look at similar towns in other states, for example, Albury-Wodonga, we find an annual growth rate of 1.2 per cent; Launceston had an average annual growth rate of 0.8 per cent; in Orange and Bathurst the figure was 1.2 per cent; in Bendigo it was 1.2 per cent, and so on. In Cairns, the figure was 4.3 per cent. Even if we look at Townsville as an example, there is clearly a very good case on the basis of these figures for Queensland not to get 25 per cent more than one would expect it to get but to get about 50 per cent more than it would entitled to, purely on the basis of population.

Senator Bolkus raised the issue of population growth; I did not. I am merely answering the flawed points that Senator Bolkus attempted to make this afternoon. Of course, we do not even come to the question of the 4.3 per cent growth in Cairns. How Senator Bolkus seems to think that we can achieve fair and equitable access to higher education in Cairns with a growth rate of 4.3 per cent and no university campus at all is quite beyond me, as I am sure it is quite beyond every rational member of this Senate. But then we are talking about an unclever Government that boasts about attempting to create a clever country.

In reality, we see a stark picture of educational desolation for the young people of Queensland. What we see in northern Queensland is particularly disturbing because, in northern Queensland, there is an educational lock-out. In spite of how much students might want to go to university, in spite of how well qualified those students may be, they do not have a university campus that they can attend. For many of those students in far northern Queensland, areas that have been particularly hard hit by the current Labor Government engineered recession, the suggestion that the students should travel down to Brisbane and live in student accommodation there is quite patently ridiculous because they do not have the money and they do not have the opportunity to get the money that they would need to pay for that accommodation as well as the cost of education itself.

A final fact that I put before the Senate is the general level of participation rates in higher education in northern Queensland compared with other areas of Australia. In northern Queensland, as I have said, the participation rate is 12 per thousand. In central Queensland, in the Fitzroy area, in the central west, and in Mackay, the participation rate is 17 per thousand. Yet, when one looks at areas such as Sydney, the participation rate is 25 per thousand; in Canberra, it is 30 per thousand; in Melbourne, it is 29 per thousand; and in Barwon in Victoria, where Deakin University is situated, the participation rate is 37 per thousand. Quite clearly, on the basis of these figures-these are not figures which I have produced myself, but are derived from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates of residential population in June 1989-this Government stands condemned for its ineptitude or, failing that, its unwillingness to address the problem of unmet demand for higher education.

Let us just put a human face on all of those figures. Let us talk about the very talented young Australians in Cairns, on Cape York Peninsula, and in other areas of northern Queensland, who have hopes and aspirations of going on to a better life, to a more prosperous life and to a more fulfilling life, than they are currently offered. For those young Australians, their hopes have been dashed by this Labor Government. Their hopes have been dashed by a government which tries to pretend that merely playing catch-up with years and years of neglect somehow redresses the very real problems of today.

I find it slightly ironic that at no time in the 23 years of conservative government from 1949 to 1972, at no time during the eight years of the Fraser Government nor at any time during the three years of the Whitlam Government did we see the creation of a private university. In fact, it is only during the years of neglect under this Federal Labor Government, under this Hawke Labor Government, that we have seen the creation of a private university-the Bond University on the Gold Coast. The irony is that that university was not created out of ideological reasons, out of a belief that the educational system should be freed up because, as Senator Teague has so ably said today, that organisation seems more interested in its centralist policies with regard to education than freeing up the education system.

The only reason that that educational facility at Bond University was established was the neglect of the Labor Government, the unmet demand, the aspirations of so many thousands of talented young Australians whose dreams were being dashed by this Government's neglect. That is why I have a great deal of pleasure and why I am very proud to say that I shall be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Teague. I should also say that it brings me a great deal of sadness that we should have to move this amendment at all. If this Government refuses to wake up, we are forced to open its eyes for it and to show it the real nature of the world outside and the real suffering which its educational neglect has caused.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Sunday I had the great pleasure to convene the first session of far north Queensland's first youth congress at Lake Tinaroo. The Far North Queensland Youth Congress is my attempt to redress some of the educational difficulties suffered by young people in far north Queensland. It basically entails four students selected from each high school in far north Queensland coming to Cairns and its surrounding area on one day each month over a period of three months to meet together to discuss the problems confronting contemporary young Australians and to offer their solutions to these problems.

SPEECH.PARA: It was with great satisfaction that I noted that we had an excellent turnout at the first youth congress. In fact, we had some 80 students from all over the far north, and as far as I am concerned their participation was absolutely fabulous. They had a long open forum session in which the calibre of debate was superb. In fact I think it at times exceeded the calibre of debate we have heard in the Senate during various portions of the preceding year. The students also decided to prepare a number of discussion papers on topics of their choosing, to be produced over a period of 2 1/2 months and presented before the public and the media at the final Far North Queensland Youth Congress session in May.

The four topics that they chose to talk about were population growth, planning and the environment; community communications; drinking and drugs; and the difficulties associated with industry and Australian productivity. In many respects they honed in on some of the key issues facing young people in the 1990s. They were concerned, as I am sure many young Australians are concerned, about the prospect that they may leave school to go to a workplace that has no place for them.

These are the problems which they echoed throughout the session and which they attempted to address in the best fashion they could. Some of the things they asked were: why is it that we have to import goods from overseas; why is it that Australian workers are as unproductive as they are; and why is it that Australia's raw materials go overseas only to be imported again in a finished state? These are questions which we often debate in the Senate and I very much look forward to the contribution which these young Australians have to make to the level of debate in these areas.

One of the very pleasing things about the youth congress is the fact that the young people involved will have their say free from any influence or bias. I very much look forward to what they have to say and I will encourage them to talk with as many people as they possibly can in forming their views. In fact, one of the things they asked me-and I was very pleased they asked it-was whether I thought it was a good idea for them to contact unions to ask them their opinions on questions about Australian productivity. I said, yes, it would be a good idea and I encouraged them to do so, because young people need to have a balanced view and a balanced debate. For my part, I am very pleased that I can in some small way contribute to this balanced debate and to what these young people have to say about the future of the nation.

I note with some satisfaction that during my recent private trip to Hungary I met with the leaders of a party called Fijdesz, which is the only existing youth party in the world. The members of Fijdesz in the Hungarian Parliament all have to be below the age of 35. For many of the young people attending the youth congress, 35 may seem an enormously advanced age but, in the context of politics both in Australia and elsewhere around the world, 35 is a very youthful age. The young people in Fijdesz currently enjoy the highest popularity rating of any political party in Hungary. They enjoy that popularity rating because of the youthful vigour with which they attack the problems faced by their nation. I only hope-and I am sure that I will see-that the young people of far north Queensland attack Australia's problems and the problems of far north Queensland with a similar, if not better, youthful vigour. I believe that the solutions and suggestions that they will make to solve the problems of the region will indeed be creative and imaginative and a tribute to their skills and to themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief remarks about a local event I was proud to be associated with during last weekend, when I was invited to officially open the Nambrok-Denison reunion of 40 years of the soldier settlement scheme in that area of central Gippsland. Nambrok-Denison is in Victoria and I, of course, am a senator from South Australia. Honourable senators may therefore well ask why I was invited to open such a reunion. I admit proudly that I grew up on one of the farms in that area during the 1950s and early 1960s. The farmers invited me back there as one of the school kids who went through the education system at the Nambrok State School and on to Sale High School, who ultimately became a member of parliament. SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the organising committee on organising a splendid array of events over Saturday and Sunday, with a lot of historic memorabilia about the development of that area of central Gippsland in the 1950s and 1960s in particular under one of the soldier settlement programs for returned servicemen from the Second World War. My father was one of those returned servicemen and was lucky enough to be allocated a dairy farm in the settlement. Looking back on it from our perspective of the development of world agriculture, it is clear that no State or Federal government would again commit itself to the funds to develop such a program. However, in the 1950s we all believed, quite rightly, that the world was our oyster as far as agricultural production was concerned. Even the First World was short of food, so whatever we produced in the agricultural area had a reasonable market, and dairy produce was no exception.

The development of nearly 200 farms in that area went ahead with the commitment of the State and Federal governments to provide the funds. It was a fully irrigated district and, interestingly, the whole program went ahead with no en- vironmental impact statement. In those days that sort of thing was not considered necessary or had even been heard of. I imagine that if any similar program were put forward today there would be an extensive environmental debate about the pros and cons of irrigation for such a project. Above all else, I do not think any government of any political persuasion would now, with the state of world agricultural prices, be willing to commit the funds needed to develop a project similar to the Nambrok-Denison soldier settlement area. In some senses one can become rather sad about that, because in the 1950s we had a new community develop. People came together from a very wide range of backgrounds and from around Australia and created, literally from the ground up, a new community of families which were successful in developing a very efficient dairy industry which still today is efficient not only by Australian standards but by world standards.

If we travel through the area we note that it is still a prosperous area. It has its problems-no-one denies that-but it was successful. In some ways it is sad that governments will not be able to make similar commitments for such closer settlement programs in the future because of the changing nature of world agriculture.

In conclusion, the people of Nambrok-Denison can be very proud of what they have achieved over 40 years. As I say, they all started from scratch with very little personal support and built a community that has thrived to this day-a community that has developed a whole range of social and sporting clubs, provided education for the kids and opportunities for the children who chose not to continue as dairy farmers-and I was one of them-but to go on and make their mark elsewhere in the world.

The fortieth reunion of the Nambrok-Denison settlement program was a very sentimental occasion for me. I was very honoured that I was asked to do the official opening but, above all else, I was very pleased to be able to pay tribute to the hard work of the soldier settlers of the 1950s who established a unique community that still thrives today.

It has confirmed that it has complied with the law and suspended all military assistance and new economic aid to Pakistan due to the absence of certification at the beginning of the new U.S. fiscal year. It has stated that the matter remains under discussion between the U.S. and Pakistan.
(3) The particular issue of the operation of U.S. legislation is a bilateral matter between the U.S. and Pakistan.

The question of nuclear proliferation is, however, a major concern to the Government. The Government has long given strong and active support to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and to the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards system, and is working hard with other governments to ensure that the nuclear nonproliferation regime remains effective in the 1990s. Nuclear proliferation in South Asia is not in the interest of either India or Pakistan, nor in the interest of regional or international security.

The Government has made clear its concern to the Governments of Pakistan and India. It has consistently urged both countries to demonstrate conclusively that they are not pursuing a nuclear weapons option by joining the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons or at the very least by placing all their nuclear facilities under fullscope safeguards.

(4) Given that the Government regards suspension of U.S. aid as a bilateral matter between Pakistan and the United States, the conduct of our trade relationship with Pakistan will not be affected. As Pakistan is not a member of the NPT, it is not an approved destination for Australian uranium.
Nuclear and other sensitive exports to any destination are subject to stringent control under the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 23 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action is the Government taking to address the problem of Indonesian fishing vessels poaching in Australian waters.
(2) What happens to the boats when these vessels are captured and taken into custody.
(3) How are the large amounts of Trochus shells found on these vessels disposed of.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The illegal fishing issue is complex and no single solution has been identified. Although a range of measures to redress the problem can be employed, the main option for deterring illegal fishing activity is the maintenance of a high level of surveillance and enforcement in the north and north western areas of the Australian Fishing Zone (AFZ). The issue is an important matter on the Australian-Indonesian bilateral agenda and the Indonesian Government is cooperating fully in attempts to resolve the problem. Australia provides the Indonesian Government with intelligence (eg on financiers) obtained from Indonesian fishermen who are apprehended for poaching.

The strong financial incentive to seek trochus and shark fin continues, even though the risks of apprehension are high. The surveillance program for the northwest and the procedures for processing and sentencing Indonesian fishermen are being reviewed to ensure that the maximum deterrent effect, consistent with our international obligations, is achieved in a cost effective way. Longer term solutions may include the development of alternative income generating opportunities for the relevant Indonesian communities in eastern Indonesia, eg trochus and seaweed culture. A significant proportion of the Australian aid vote to Indonesia is already directed to the eastern provinces.

(2) When a boat is taken into custody by fisheries authorities, both the boat and crew are first inspected by Quarantine Officers for quarantine problems. The boat is then taken to a holding area where it is held until Court proceedings have concluded. If the boats are forfeited as a result of those Court proceedings, the boats are disposed of in accordance with procedures set down by the Department of Administrative Services and the Australian Fisheries Service.
(3) When a boat has been apprehended a small quantity of shell is retained as evidence in Court proceedings that follow, the remainder of the shell is returned to the reef.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 14 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What special entitlements accrue to all Australian military personnel currently stationed in the war zone of the Persian Gulf.
(2) At what date did these entitlements commence.
(3) How many Australian military personnel are currently serving with the United States and British armed forces presently stationed in the Persian Gulf.
(4) What is their status and under whose command do they operate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian Defence Force personnel deployed to the Middle East in response to the invasion of Kuwait, including those personnel deployed with US and UK forces are entitled to the following special conditions of service:

a. Gulf Allowance at the rate of $45 for each day, or part of a day, the member is on duty in the operational area. Personnel on RAN ships which temporarily leave the operational area continue to receive Gulf Allowance at the rate of $30 a day for a maximum period of 10 days.

b. Tax Exemption of all pay and allowances earned from the date of deployment to the Gulf until the date of return to Australia or their overseas base. For personnel that do not return directly to Australia the tax exemption ceases on their arrival in another overseas location.
c. War Service Leave at the rate of one and a half days for each completed month served in the operational area.

d. Repatriation Benefits under the Veteran's Entitlement Act from departure from Australia or their overseas base until return to Australia or their overseas base including eligibility to apply for a Service (Age) Pension at age 60 for males and age 55 for females.
e. Home Loan Benefits under either the Defence Service Homes Loan or the ADF Home Loan Assistance Scheme, depending on their date of enlistment.
(2) All these benefits came into effect from 2 August 1990.
(3) As at 4 March 1991, 30 Australian Defence Force Personnel were serving on exchange with coalition forces stationed in the Persian Gulf. This figure fluctuates daily.

(4) ADF personnel posted on exchange to United States or British units serving in the Persian Gulf area are fully integrated into the unit to which they are assigned and operate under the control of the national operational authority of that particular unit. Authorisation for ADF personnel on exchange service to deploy to the Gulf area with their assigned foreign unit is approved by the Department of Defence on a case by case basis.
